editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE SONGS OF THE OLD AND NEW TESTAMENT IN MEETER:
By M. ZACHARY BOYD Preacher of Gods Word.
div.q: Be ye filled with the Spirit, &c.
Speaking to your selves in Psalmes, and Hymnes, and spirituall Songs, singing and making melody in your heart to the Lord.
div.p: GLASGOW, Printed by the Heires of GEORGE ANDERSON. Anno 1648.

div.head: The Songs of the Old and New Testament.

list.item: The Song of Moses at the red Sea. 2.
The song of Moses a little before his death 3
Davids lamentations for: Saul and Ionathan. 6
The song of David at the promise of Messias. 7
The song of Isaiah concerning the vineyard. 8
Isaiahs song of thanks for Gods mercies. 9
Isaiahs song inciting to confidence in God. 10
The Lamentations of Ierem â€¢ ah. 12
The song of Zachari â€¢ s. 16

div.head: To the right Reverend, the faithfull Ministers of GODS Word of the Church of Scotland.
div.p:
IT pleased You in the Generall Assembly last, at Edinburgh, Anno 1647. to take to your consideration, the great utility the Church of GOD may have by the Songs contained in holy Scriptures; After due deliberation, it pleased You to ordain that I should labour in that work â€¢ In obedience unto You, I have endeavoured to come as neer to the Text as was possible for me to do; And those my labours I in all humility
offer to be considered, by the most learned and most judicious Brethren, that the Church having the use thereof, may in obedience to the Apostles precept Ephes. 5. 18. in Psalmes, and Hymnes, and spirituall Songs, make melody in their heart to the Lord, whom I intreat in all humility to direct You in all things by his holy Spirit; So I remain

closer.signed: Your humble servant in the LORD, M. ZACHARY BOYD.

div.head: THE SONG OF Solomon made in praise of Christ, and his Church.
CHAPTER I.
div.p: LEt him kisse me with the kisses of his mouth, for thy love is better then wine.

lg.l: LEt him with kisses of his mouth
to kisse me now incline,
For sure thy love farre better is
then is the finest wine.

div.p: 2 Because of the savour of thy good oyntments, thy name is as oyntment powred forth, therefore do the virgins love thee.

lg.l: Because that of thine ointments â€¢ ood
the savour sweet doth prove,
Thy Name as ointment forth is powr'd
thee therefore virgins love.

div.p: 3 Draw me, we will run after thee: the King hath brought me into his chambers:

lg.l: Do thou me draw and then anone
we after thee will run:
The King himself he hath me now
his chambers brought within.

div.p: We will be glad and rejoice in thee, we will remember thy love more then wine: the upright love thee.

lg.l: We'l in thee glade be and rejoice,
thy love also will wee
Remeber more then sinest wine,
the upright do love thee.

div.p: 4 I am black, but comely, (O ye daughters of Ierusalem) as the tents of Kedar, as the curtains of Solomon.

lg.l: O Salems daughters black I am,
but yet a comely one
As tents of Kedar, and ev'n as
curtains of Solomon.

div.p: 5 Look not upon me because I am black, because the Sun hath looked upon me.

lg.l: Upon me look not ye, because
I black do seem to be,
Because the Sun hath with his beames
long looked upon me.

div.p: My mothers children were angry with mee, they made me the keeper of the vineyards, but mine own vineyard have I not kept.

lg.l: My mothers children wroth with me
the vineyards keeper made,
But I my self have not at all
so kept mine own vineyard.

div.p: 6 Tell me (O thou whom my soul loveth) where thou feedest, where thou makest thy flock to rest at noon:

lg.l: O thou, whom dearly loves my soul,
I pray thee tell me soon
Where thou dost feed, and where thou makst
thy flock to rest at noon.

div.p: For why should I be as one that turneth aside by the flocks of thy companions?

lg.l: For why should I be any way
as one that turnes aside
By flocks of thy companions
where ev'r they do abide?

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: 7 If thou know not, (O thou fairest among women) go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock, and feed thy kids beside the shepherds tents.

lg.l: O fairest one if thou not know,
by the flocks footsteps go,
And do thou feed thy kids beside
the shepherds tents also.

sp.p: 8 I have compared thee, O my love, to a company of horses in Pharaohs chariots.

lg.l: My love unto a company
I have compared thee,
Of horses in the chariots
that for King Pharo be.

sp.p: 9 Thy cheeks are comely with rows of jewels, thy neck with chains of gold.
10 We will make thee borders of gold with studs of silver.

lg.l: With jewell rows thy cheeks are fair,
with chaines of gold thy neck:
Of gold we borders will thee make
which silver studs do deck.

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p: 11 While the king sitteth at his table, my spikenard sendeth forth the smell thereof.
12 A bundle of myrrhe is my welbeloved unto me;

lg.l: While at his table sits the King
my spiknard sends it smell:
Of mirrhe a bundle unto me
is my beloved well.

sp.p: He shall ly all night betwixt my breasts.
13 My beloved is unto me, as a cluster of Camphire, in the vineyards of Engedi.

lg.l: Betwixt my breasts hee'le lie all night
My welbelov'd's to me
As of Engedies vineyards rare,
the Camphires clusters beâ–ª

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: 14 Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair, thou hast doves eyes.

lg.l: O do behold, most fair thou art
ev'n thou my love so rare,
Behold of Doves the eyes thou hast,
and thou art very fair.

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p: 15 Behold, thou art fair, my beloved, yea pleasant: also our bed is green.
16 The beams of our house are cedar, and our rafters of fire.

lg.l: Lo, pleasant fair thou art my love,
green also is our bed:
Beams of our house they cedars are,
of firre our rafters made.

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: I Am the rose of Sharon, and the lilly of the valleyes.
2 As the lilly among thornes, so is my love among the daughters.

lg.l: I'M Sharons rose, the lilly als
that valleyes growes along:
As lillies among thornes, my love
so daughters is among.

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p: 3 As the apple tree among the trees of the wood, so is my beloved among the sons.

lg.l: As th â€¢ apple tree among the trees
is of the wood so throng,
So likewise my Beloved is,
the sons of men among.

sp.p: â€¢ I sate down under his shadow with great delight, and his fruit was sweet to my taste.

lg.l: Under his shadow I sate down
with great delight there plac't,
And there his fruit which pleasant is
was sweet unto my taste.

sp.p: 4 He brought me to the banqueting house, and his banner over me was love.

lg.l: Unto the house of banquetingâ–ª
to come he did me moveâ–ª
His banner that was over me
was altogether love.

sp.p: 5 Stay me with flagons, comfort me with apples; for I am sick of love.
6 His left hand is under my head, and his right hand doth embrace me.

lg.l: Me sick of love with flagons stay,
with apples me solace:
Under my head his left hand is,
his right me doth embrace.

sp.p: 7 I charge you, O ye daughters of Ierusalem, by the Roes, and by the Hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake my love till he please.

lg.l: By Roes, field Hindes, O Salems maids,
I charge you that ye cease
â€¢ o stir or yet at all awake
my love, untill he please.

sp.p:
8 The voice of my beloved! behold, he co
â€¢ eth leaping upon the mountains, skipping upon
â€¢â€¢ e hils.

lg.l: The voice of my Belov'd! behold!
he cometh thus anone
â€¢ pon the mountains leaping high
and skipping hills upon.

sp.p:
9 My beloved is like a roe, or a young hart: hold, he standeth behinde our wall, he looketh
â€¢â€¢ th at the windows, shewing himself through
â€¢â€¢ e lattesse.

lg.l: He's like a Roe or Hart that's young,
he stands behind our wall,
â€¢ t windowes he looks forth, himself
he shews through lattesse all.

sp.p:
10 My beloved spake, and said unto me,
â€¢ se up my love, my faire one, and come away.

11 For lo, the winter is past, the raine is over
â€¢â€¢ d gone.

lg.l: Then my Belov'd said, Rise my love,
away come my fair One:
For lo the winter it is past,
the rain is ov'r and gone.

sp.p:
12 The flowers appear on the earth, the time
â€¢ he singing of birds is come, and the voice of turtle is heard in our land.

lg.l: The flowers upon the earth appear,
of singing of the bird
The time is come; the Turtles voice
within our land is heard.

sp.p: 13 The fig-tree putteth forth her green figs and the vines with the tender grape give a good smell. Arise, my love, my faire one, and come away.

lg.l: The fig tree her green figs puts forth,
vines with grapes tender they
Do sweetly smell; arise my love
my fair one come away.

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: 14 O my dove that art in the clefts of the rock, in the secret places of the stairs,

lg.l: O thou my dove that art ev'n now
in clifts within the rock,
Within the secret places of
the staires where thou dost lurk.

sp.p: Let me see thy countenance, let me hear thy voice, for sweet is thy voice, and thy countenance is comely.

lg.l: Let thou me see thy countenance,
thy voice let thou me hear,
For sweet thy voice is, and also
thy countenance is clear.

sp.p: 15 Take us the Foxes, the little foxes that spoile the vines: for our vines have tender grapes.

lg.l: Do ye for us the foxes take,
foxes that little be
That spoile the vines, for tender grapes
our vines have, as ye see.

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p:
16 My beloved is mine, and I am his: he
â€¢ eedeth among the lillies.

lg.l: My Welbeloved sure is mine,
and I am his indeed,
Among the lillies smelling sweet
he pleasantly doth feed.

sp.p:
17 Vntill the day break, and the shadowes
â€¢ lee away: turn my beloved, and be thou like a Roe, or a young Hart, upon the mountains of Bether.

lg.l: Untill day break and shads flee hence,
turn my belov'd, and be
Thou like a Roe, or Hart that's young
on Bethers mountains hie.

div.head: CHAPTER III.
div.p:
BY night on my bed I sought him whom my soul loveth: I sought him, but I found
â€¢ im not.

lg.l: BY night I did upon my bed
him seek with all my minde
VVhom my soul loveth; I him sought,
but him I did not find.

div.p: 2 I will rise now, and go about the citie in the streets, and in the broad wayes I will seek him whom my Soul loveth:

lg.l: I will now rise, and in the streets
about the city move,
And in the broad wayes I will seek
him whom my soul doth love.

div.p: I sought him, but I found him not.
3 The watchmen that goe about the city found mee: to whom I said, Saw ye him whom my Soul loveth.
div.l: I sought him, but I found him not,

lg.l: The Cities watchmen me
Did find; I said then did ye him
whom my soul loveth see?

div.p: 4 It was but a little that I passed from them, but I found him whom my Soul loveth;

lg.l: It but a little was that I
from them did passe away,
But I him whom my soul doth love
did find without delay:

div.p: I held him, and would not let him goe, untill I had brought him into my mothers house, and into the chamber of her that conceived me.

lg.l: I held and would not let him go,
untill that by me he
Was to her house and chamber brought
that had conceived me.

div.p: 5 I charge you, O ye daughters of Ierusalem, by the Roes, and by the Hindes of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake my love till hee please.

lg.l: O Salems daughters I you charge
by Roes, field Hindes ye cease
To stir or yet for to awake
my love untill he please.

div.p: 6 Who is this that cometh out of the wildernesse like pillars of smoake, perfumed with myrrhe and frankincense, with all powders of the merchant.

lg.l: Of smoak like pillars who is this
that comes from wildernesse,
Perfum'd with frankincense and mirrhe,
all merchands powders als.

div.p: 7 Behold his bed, which is Solomons: threescore valiant men are about it, of the valiant of Israel.

lg.l: Behold, his bed is Solomons,
threescore men valiant all
About it are, of those that are
the valiant of Isra'l.

div.p: 8 They all hold swords, being expert in war, Every man hath his sword upon his thigh, because of fear in the night.

lg.l: Expert in war, they all do hold
swords in their hands most bright,
â€¢ ach man his sword hath on his thigh,
because of fear by night.

div.p: 9 King Solomon made himself a charet of the wood of Lebanon.
10 He made the pillars thereof of silver, the bottom thereof of gold,

lg.l: Of Lebanons wood Solomon
himself a charet made;
It's pillars made of silver were,
with gold the bottome laid:

div.p: The covering of it of purple, the midst thereof being paved with love, for the daughters of Ierusalem.

lg.l: The cov'ring of it purple was,
the midst of it for them
Was pav'd with love, that daughters were
of his Jerusalem.

div.p: 11 Go forth, O ye daughters of Zion, and behold King Solomon,

lg.l: Oye that Zions daughters are
do ye go forth anone,
And do ye with great reverence
behold king Solomon.

div.p: With the crown wherewith his mother crowned him in the day of his espousals, and in the day of the gladnesse of his heart.

lg.l: With crown wherewith his mother him
crown'd in his spousals day,
And in the day his heart was fill'd
with gladenesse ev'ry way.

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: BEhold, thou art faire, my love, behold thou art faire, thou hast doves eyes within thy locks:

lg.l: BEhold my love thou art most fairâ–ª
behold fair is thy skin,
The pure and chast eyes of the Dove
thou hast thy locks within:

sp.p:
Thy haire is as a flock of goats, that appear â€¢
from mount Gilead.

lg.l: Thy haire that is upon thy head,
is also very nearâ–ª
Like to a flock of goats that from
mount Gilead do appear.

sp.p: 2 Thy teeth are like a flock of sheep, that are even shorn which came up from the washing, whereof every one beare twins, and none is barren among them.

lg.l: Thy teeth are like a flock of sheep,
ev'n shorn from washing gone,
Whereof each one bare twins, and them
among is barren none.

sp.p: 3 Thy lips are like a threed of scarlet, and thy speach is comely: thy temples are like a prece of a pomegranate within thy locks.

lg.l: Thy speach is comely, and thy lips
like scarlet threed we see,
Within thy locks thy temples like
piece of pomgranats be.

sp.p: 4 Thy neck is like the tower of David, buil â€¢ ded for an armory, whereon there hang a thou â€¢ sand bucklers, all shields of mighty men.

lg.l: Thy neck is like King Davids tower,
built for an armorie,
Whereon a thousand bucklers hang,
mens shields that mighty be.

sp.p:
5 Thy two breasts are like two young Roe â€¢
that are twins, which feed among the lillies.

lg.l: Thy breasts in number two are like
unto two Roes indeed
That young are, and are also twins
which 'mong the lillies feed.

sp.p: 6 Vntill the day break, and the shadows flee away, I will get me to the mo â€¢ ntaine of myrrhe, and to the hill of frankincense.

lg.l: Untill the day most clearly break
and shaddows flee from hence;
I'le get me to thee mounts of Myrrhe,
and hill of frankincense.

sp.p: 7 Thou art all fair, my love, there is no spot in thee.
8 Come with me from Lebanon, my spouse, with me from Lebanon:

lg.l: Thou art all fair my love, there is
no spot at all in thee:
Spouse come with me from Lebanon
from Lebanon with me

sp.p: Look from the top of Amana, from the top of Shenir and Hermon, from the Lyons dens, from the mountains of the Leopards.

lg.l: Look from the tops of Amana,
Shenir and Hermon hie,
From Lions dens, from mountaines great
where Leopards there be.

sp.p: 9 Thou hast ravished my heart, my sister, my spouse, thou hast ravished my heart, with one of thine eyes, with one chain of thy neck.

lg.l: My heart thou ravish'd, sister, spouse,
my heart thou in effect
Hast ravish'd with one of thine eyes,
with one chain of thy neck.

sp.p: 10 How fair is thy love, my sister, my spouse, how much better is thy love then wine? and the smell of thine oyntments then all spices.

lg.l: How fair's thy love, my sister spouse?
how better much then wine
Is this thy love! thine ointments smell
more then all spices fine!

sp.p:
11 Thy lips, O my spouse drop as the hon
comb, hony and milk are under thy tongue, and the smell of thy garments is like the smell of Lebanon.

lg.l: Thy lips, Spouse, drop as hony comb,
the honey milk excell
Under thy tongue; as Lebanon
thy garments they do smell.

sp.p: 12 A garden inclosed is my sister, my spouse: a spring shut up, a fountain sealed.

lg.l: My sister spouse a garden is,
which is inclosed well,
A spring shut up, a fountain als
whereon is set a seal.

sp.p: 13 Thy plants are an orchard of Pomegranates, with pleasant fruits, Camphire, with Spikenard.

lg.l: Thy plants an orchard are also
ev'n of pomegranates rare,
With pleasant fruits, the Camphire sweet
and Spiknard likewise are:

sp.p: 14 Spikenard and Saffron, Calamus and Cynamon, with all trees of frankincense, Myrrhe, and Aloes, with all the chief spices:

lg.l: Spiknard, Saffron, and Calamus,
and Cynamon with all,
Trees of franklncense, Aloes, Mirrhe,
all spices principall.

sp.p: 15 A fountaine of gardens, a well of living waters, and streams from Lebanon.

lg.l: A fountain for to water well
the gardens all anoneâ–ª
A well of living waters als
and streames from Lebanon.

sp.speaker: The Church.

lg.l: O north wind, do thou now awake,
and come thou south about,
Upon my garden blow; that so
its spices may flow out:

sp.p: Let my beloved come into his garden, and cat his plea â€¢â€¢ nt fruits.

lg.l: Let him that my beloved is
come to his garden sweet,
That he his fruits that pleasant are
may with contentment eat.

div.head: CHAPTER V.

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: I Am come into my garden, my sister, my spouse, I have gathered my Myrrhe with my spice,

lg.l: MY sister and my spouse, I am
my garden come into,
I carefully have gathered
my mirrhe and spice also.

sp.p: I have eaten my hony comb with my honey, I have drunk my wine with my milk: eat, O friends, drink, yea drink abundantly, O beloved!

lg.l: I hony comb with hony ate,
my wine, milk, drunk have I,
Eat, O ye friends, drink O Belov'd;
yea, drink abundantly.

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p: 2 I sleep, but mine heart waketh: it is the voice of my beloved that knocketh, saying,

lg.l: I sleep securely but my heart
doth wake both night and day,
It is the voice of my Belov'd
that knocking thus doth say,

sp.p: Open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my undefiled: for my head is filled with dew, and my locks with the drops of the night.

lg.l: My Sister, Love, Dove, undefil'd,
now open to me right,
For filled is my head with dew,
my locks with drops of night.

sp.p: 3 I have put off my coat, how shall I put it on? I have washed my feet, how shall I defile them?

lg.l: I have put off my coat, how shall
I put it on a while?
I washed also have my feet
how shall I them defile?

sp.p: 4 My beloved put in his hand by the hole o the door, and my bowels were moved for him.

lg.l: By of the door the hole his hand
my Welbelov'd put in,
And for him then my bowels all
were moved me within.

sp.p:
5 I rose up to open to my beloved, and my hands dropped with Myrrhe, and my fingers with sweet smelling Myrrhe, upon the handles o â€¢
the lock.

lg.l: To open to my love I rose,
my hands with myrrhe did drop,
My fingers with sweet smelling myrrhe
on handles of the lock.

sp.p: 6 I opened to my beloved, but my beloved had withdrawn himself, and was gone:

lg.l: To my Belov'd I op'ned then,
but my Belov'd alone
Withdrawn himself had farre away,
and from the door was gone:

sp.p: My soul failed: when he spake I sought him but I could not finde him: I called him, but he gave me no answer.

lg.l: My soul it failed when he spake,
I after him did crave,
But could not find him, I him call'd,
but he no answer gave.

sp.p: 7 The watchmen that went about the citie, found me, they smote mee, they wounded me, the keepers of the walls took away my vaile from me.

lg.l: The cities watchmen found me then,
me smot, me wounded they,
The keepers of the wals they took
my vail from me away.

sp.p: 8 I charge you, O daughters of Ierusalem, if ye finde my beloved, that ye tell him, that I am sick of love.

lg.l: O daughters of Jerusalem
I charge you from above,
If my Belov'd ye find, that yee
him tell, I'm sick of love.

div.p: 9 What is thy beloved more then another beloved, O thou fairest among women? what is thy beloved more then another beloved, that thou dost so charge us?

lg.l: O fairest, among women thou
what's thy Beloved more?
What is he more then others are,
that thou dost charge so sore?

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p: 10 My beloved is white and ruddy, the chiefest among ten thousand.
11 His head is as the most fine gold, his looks are bushie and black as a raven.

lg.l: Both white and rudy's my Belov'd,
chief among thousands ten:
His head's as gold, his bushy locks
are black as is a rav'n.

sp.p: ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ His eyes are as the eyes of doves by the rivers of waters, washed with milk and fitly set.

lg.l: His eyes are as the eyes of doves
that by the rivers sit,
They washed also are with milk
and they are fitly set.

sp.p: 13 His cheeks are as a bed of spices, as sweet flowres: his lips like lillies, dropping sweet smelling myrrhe.

lg.l: His cheeks are as the spices bed,
as flowers that sweet excell,
His lips like lillies droping Myrrhe,
that hath the sweetest smell.

sp.p: 14 His hands are as gold rings set with the Berill: His belly is as bright ivory, overlaid with Saphires.

lg.l: His hands as goldrings als are set
with Berill richly made,
His belly as bright ivory is
with Saphires overlaid.

sp.p: 15 His legs are as pillars of marble, set upon sockets of fine gold: his countenance is as Lebanon, excellent as the Cedars.

lg.l: His legs like Marble pillars are,
on fine gold sockers set;
His count'nance is as Lebanon,
as Cedars passing great.

sp.p: 16 His mouth is most sweet: yea, he is altogether lovely: This is my beloved, and this is my friend, O daughters of Ierusalem.

lg.l: Most sweet his mouth is, yea he is
most lovely altogether:
This my Belov'd, and this my Friend
is, O thou Salems daughter.

div.head: CHAPTER VI.
div.p: WHether is thy beloved gone? O thou fairest among women, whether is thy beloved turned aside? that we may seek him with thee.

lg.l: O Whither's thy Beloved gone,
of women all most fair?
O whither turn'd, that we with thee
may seek him, now declare?

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p: 2 My beloved is gone down into his garden, to the beds of spices, to feed in the gardens, and to gather lillies.

lg.l: Into his garden my Belov'd
to beds of spices rare,
To feed in gardens is gone down
to gather lillies there.

sp.p: 3 I am my beloveds, and my beloved is mines be feedeth among the lillies.

lg.l: My Welbeloveds I am all,
and my Belov'd Indeed
Is likewise mine: and now he doth
among the lillies feed.

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: 4 Thou art beautifull, O my love as Tirzah comely as Ierusalem, terrible as an army with banners.

lg.l: My love as Tirza beautifull
as Salem comely so
Thou art; as one host terrible
that doth with banners go.

sp.p: 5 Turne away thine eyes from me for they have overcome me: thy hair is as a flock of goats that appear from Gilead.

lg.l: From me thine eyes turn thou away,
for they me overcome,
Thy hair is as a flock of goats
from Gilead that do come.

sp.p: 6 Thy teeth are as a flock of sheep which go up from the washing, whereof every one beareth twins, and there is not one barren among them.

lg.l: Thy teeth are as a flock of sheep,
which go from washing throng:
Eacl â€¢ one bears twins, and there is not
one barren them among.

sp.p: 7 As a piece of a pomegranate are thy temples within thy locks.

lg.l: The temples also of thine head
within thy locks that ly,
As of a pomegtanate a piece
do seem right pleasantly.

sp.p: 8 There are threescore Queens, and fourescore Concubines, and Virgins without number.

lg.l: Though threescore of fair queens there be,
and concubines fourscore,
And virgins als them to attend,
ev'n without number more.

sp.p: 9 My dove, my undefiled is but one: she is the only one of her mother, she is the choice one of her that bare her:

lg.l: My Dove my undefild's but one,
she of her mother â€¢ ale
Is th'onely one, and she the choise
is of her that her bare.

sp.p: The daughters saw her, and blessed herâ–ª yea, the Queens and the Concubines and they praised her.

lg.l: The daughters of the land her saw,
and blessed her likewise,
Yea ev'n the Queens and Concubines and they als did her praise.

sp.p: 10 Who is she that looketh foorth as the morning, fair as the moon clear as the sun, and terrible as an army with banners?

lg.l: Who's she as morning that looks forth,
fair as the Moon, and clear
As is the sun, and armies as
that dreadfull banners bear.

sp.p: 11 I went down into the garden of nuts, to see the fruits of the valley, and to see whether the vine flourished, and the pomegranates budded.

lg.l: I down to the Nut-garden went
the valleys fruits to see:
To see if vines were flouri â€¢ h'd, and
pomegranates budded be.

sp.p: 12 Or ever I was aware, my soul made me like the chariots of Amminadab.

lg.l: Or ever then I was aware,
my soul i â€¢ at the last
Like charets of Aminadab
made me to make great hast.

sp.p: 13 Return, return, O Shulamite, return, return, that we may look upon thee:

lg.l: Return, return O Shulamite,
return, return to me:
That we with gladnesse great of heart
may so now look on thee;

sp.p: What will ye see in the Shulamite? as it were the company of two armies.

lg.l: What will ye in the Shulamite
with great contentment see?
Ev'n such a sight as if it were
two Armies companie.

div.head: CHAPTER VII.
div.p:
HOw beautifull are thy feet with sho â€¢ es, O Princes daughter, the joynts of thy thighs are like jewels, the work of the hands of a cun
â€¢ ing work-man.

lg.l: HOw beatifull thy feet with shoes
O Princes daughter are!
Joints of thy thighs are jewels like
wrought by a work-man rare.

div.p: 2 Thy navell is like a round goblet, which wanteth not licour: thy belly is like an heap of wheat, set about with lillies.

lg.l: Thy navel's like a goblet round,
which liquor wanteth not:
Thy belly's like an heap of wheat,
with lillies set about.

div.p: 3 Thy two breasts are like two young Roes, that are twins.
4 Thy neck is as a tower of ivory: thine eyes like the fish pooles in Heshbon, by the gate of Bathrabbim:

lg.l: Thy breasts are like two twin young Roes:
Thy neck, thine eyes like Heshbons pools
hard by Bathrabbims gate.

div.p: Thy nose is as the towre of Lebanon, which looketh toward Damascus.

lg.l: Thy nose it is ev'n like the towre
that is in Lebanon,
Which toward all the city of
Damascus looketh down.

div.p: 5 Thine head upon thee is like Carmell, and the haire of thine head like purple, the King is held in the galleries.

lg.l: Thy head on thee is Carmel like,
als of thine head the hair
Is Purple like, the King is held
in galleries most rare.

div.p: 6 How faire, and how pleasant art thou, O Love, for delights!
7 This thy stature is like to a palme tree, and thy breasts to clusters of grapes.

lg.l: O love how art thou for delights
both pleasant and how fair!
Thy stature â€¢ 's like palme trees, thy breasts
they like grapes clusters are.

div.p: 8 I said, I will go up to the palme tree, I will take hold of the boughs thereof,

lg.l: I did then say that I go up
unto the palme tree wold,
Yea of the boughs thereof I will
with all my force take hold.

div.p: Now also thy breasts shall be as clusters of the vine, and the smell of thy nose like apples.

lg.l: Now also shall thy breasts all be
as clusters of the vine,
And of thy nose the pleasant smell
like apples that are fine.

div.p: 9 And the roofe of thy mouth like the best wine for my beloved, that goeth down sweetly, causing the lips of those that are asleep, to speak.

lg.l: Roof of thy mouth like best wine is
that sweetly down doth go
For my Belov'd, and sleepers lips
doth cause to speak also.

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p: 10 I am my beloveds, and his dosire is towards me.
11 Come my beloved, let us go forth into the field:

lg.l: I my Beloveds am, and his
desire is towards me,
Come my Belov'd, unto the field,
let us forth going be,

sp.p: Let us lodge in the villages.
12 Let us get up early to the vineyards, let us see if the vine flourish,

lg.l: Let us lodge in the villages:
Up early get to be
At vineyards, if so that the vines
do flourish let us see:

sp.p: Whether the tender grapesappear, and the pomegranates bud forth: there will I give thee my loves.

lg.l: Ev'n whether tender grapes appear,
and pomegranates bud forth,
There surely will I give to thee
my loves of greatest worth.

sp.p:
â€¢ 3 The mandraks give a smell, and at our gates are all manner of pleasant fruits, new and old which I have laid up for thee, O my
â€¢ eloved.

lg.l: The mandrakes smell, and at our gates
all pleasant fruits there be,
Both new and old, which I laid up,
O my Belov'd for thee.

div.head: CHAPTER VIII.
div.p: O That thou wert as my brother that sucked the breasts of my mother, when I should find thee without,

lg.l: O That thou as my brother wert
that of my mother kind
Did suck the breasts, even at what time
I thee without should find.

div.p: I would kisse thee, yet I should not be despised.
2 I would lead thee, and bring thee into my mothers house, who would instruct me:

lg.l: I would thee kisse, yet not be loth'd
Yea I would thee conduct,
And bring thee to my mothers house
who would me there instruct.

div.p: I would cause thee to drink of spiced wine, of the juice of my pomegranate.

3 His left hand should be under my head:
â€¢ nd his right hand should embrace me.

lg.l: â€¢ would thee cause drink spiced wine
of my pomegranats juice:
Under my head his left hand laid,
his right should me embrace.

div.p:
4 I charge you, O daughters of Ierusalem,
â€¢ hat ye stirre not up, nor awake my love untill he please.

lg.l: O daughters of Jerusalem,
I charge you that you cease
To stir up or awake my love,
and that untill he please.

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: 5 Who is this that cometh up from the wildernesse, leaning upon her beloved?

lg.l: Who is this from the wildernesse
that comes up by and by?
And thus on her Beloved One
doth leaning still rely?

sp.p: I raised thee up under the apple tree: there thy mother brought thee foorth, there she brought thee foorth that bare thee.

lg.l: Under the aple tree I thee â€¢
did raise up being there,
Thy mother there thee did bring sorth,
she brought forth that thee bare.

sp.speaker: Iewish Church.
sp.p: 6 Set me as a seal upon thine heart, as a seal upon thine arme: For love is strong as death, jealousie is cruell as the grave:

lg.l: Me as a seal upon thine heart
as seal on arme m'ingrave:
For love's as death strong, jealousie
is cruell as the grave.

sp.p: The coals thereof are coals of fire, which hath a most vehement flame.

7 Many waters cannot quench love, neith â€¢
can the flouds drown it:

lg.l: The coals there of are coals of fire,
which hath a vehement flame:
The waters great, love can not quench
nor floods can drown the same.

sp.p:
If a man would give all the substance of â€¢
house for love, It would utterly be contemned

lg.l: If of his house the substance all
a man for love to buy
Would gladely give, yet would it be
contemned utterly.

sp.p:
8 We have a little sister, and she hath ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
breasts, what shall we do for our sister, in ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
day when she shall be spoken for?

lg.l: We have a little sister, which
no breasts hath lesse or more,
What shall we for her do the day
she shall be spoken for?

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p:
9 If she be a wall, we will build upon her palace of silver: and if she be a door, we ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
inclose her with boards of Cedar.

lg.l: If â€¢ he a wall be, we'l on her
a palace build of silver;
If she a door be, we her will
inclose with boards of Cedar.

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p: 10 I am a wall, and my breasts like towersâ–ª then was I in his eyes as one that found favour.

lg.l: I am a wall, my breasts they are
like towrs upon the ground,
Then was I in his eyes as one
that had his favour found.

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: 11 Solomon had a vineyard at Baal-hamon, he let out the vineyard unto keepers:

lg.l: At Baal-Hamon a vineyard
king Solomon had set;
The vineyard unto keepers he
for profite out had let.

sp.p: Every one for the fruit thereof was to bring a thousand pieces of silver.

lg.l: Of those his servants evry one
for the fruit of the vine
A thousand pieces was to bring
of silver that was fine.

sp.p: 12 My vineyard which is mine, is before me: thou (O Solomon) must have a thousand, and those that keep the fruit thereof, two hundred.

lg.l: My vineyard mine before me is,
thou must O Solomon
A thousand have; who keep its fruits
two hundred live upon,

sp.p:
13 Thou that dwellest in the gardens, th â€¢
companions hearken to thy voice, cause me ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
hear it.

lg.l: O thou that in the gardens fair
most pleasantly dost dwell,
Companions hearken to thy voice,
cause me to hear it well.

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p:
14 Make haste, my beloved, and be thou lik â€¢
â€¢â€¢ to a Roe, or to a young Hart, upon the mountain â€¢
of spices.

lg.l: Make hast my Welbelov'd, and be
thou like unto a Ro,
Or unto a young Hart that doth
on hills of spices go.

div.head: The Song of Moses at the Red Sea, after God had drowned Pharao and his whole hoast. EXODUS 15. 1.
div.p:
I Will sing unto the Lord, for he hath trium â€¢ phed gloriously; the horse and his rider h â€¢â€¢â€¢
he thrown into the sea.

lg.l: I To the Lord will sing, for he
triumph'd hath gloriously;
The horse he and his rider als
hath thrown into the sea.
The Lord my strength is and my song,
and he is my salvation,
He is my God, and I'le prepare
for him an habitation.

div.p: My fathers God, and I will exalt him.

3 The Lord is a man of war: the Lord is
â€¢ is Name.

lg.l: He is my fathers God, and I
will high exalt his fame:
The Lord he is a man of warre,
JEHOVAH is his Name.

div.p:
4 Pharaohs chariots and his host hath he cast
â€¢ nto the sea: his chosen captains also are drown
â€¢ d in the Red sea.

lg.l: He Pharos charets and his hoast
hath cast into the sea:
Now in the red sea also drown'd
his chosen captains be.

div.p:
5 The depths have covered them, they sank
â€¢ nto the bottome as a stone.

lg.l: The fearfull depths they likewise have,
them covered eachone,
â€¢ nto the bottom headlongs they
then sank as doth a stone.

div.p:
6 Thy right hand, O Lord is become glori
â€¢ us in power; thy right hand, O Lord, hath dash
â€¢ d in pieces the enemy.

lg.l: Thy right hand Lord it is become
in power glorious all,
Thy right hand Lord the enemy
hath da â€¢ h'd in pieces small.

div.p: 7 And in the greatnesse of thine excellencie thou hast overthrown them that rose up against thee; thou sentest forth thy wrath, which consumed them as stubble.

lg.l: Who 'gainst thee rose them thou ov'rthrew,
in great excellency,
Thy wrath thou sentest forth which them
consum'd as stubble dry.

div.p: 8 And with the blast of thy nostrils, the waters were gathered together: the floods stood upright as an heap, and the depths were congealed in the heart of the sea.

lg.l: The waters at thy nostrils blast,
together gathred were:
Floods stood as heaps, in heart of sea,
the depths congeal'd were there.

div.p: 9 The enemy said, I will pursue, I will overtake, I will divide the spoile: my lust shall be satisfied upon them:

lg.l: The en'my said, I will pursue,
I'le overtake anone,
I'le part the spoile; my lust shall be
them satisfi'd upon;

div.p: I will draw my sword, my hand shall destroy them.
10 Thou didst blow with thy wind, the sea covered them, they sank as lead in the mighty wa â€¢ ers.

lg.l: I'le draw my sword, my hand it shall
destroy them all indeed:
Thy wind blew, seas them cov â€¢â€¢ d, they in
great waters sank as lead:

div.p: 11 Who is like unto thee, O Lord, amongst the gods? who is like thee, glorious in holinesse, fearfull in praises, doing wonders?

lg.l: Who's like thee Lord among the gods
who's like thee glorious
In holinesse, fearfull in praise
and doing wonders thus?

div.p: 12 Thou stretchedst out thy right hand, the earth swallowed them.
13 Thou in thy mercy hast led forth the people which thou hast redeemed:

lg.l: Thy right hand then thou stretched out,
earth swallow'd them at last.
In mercy thou the folk ledst forth
which thou redeemed hast:

div.p:
Thou hast guided them in thy strength unto
â€¢ hy holy habitation.

14 The people shall hear, and be afraid:
â€¢ orrow shall take hold on the inhabitants of Palestina.
div.l: Thou hast them to thy holy house

lg.l: Men shall hear, fear, grief shall them seiz
in Palestine that dwell:

div.p: 15 Then the dukes of Edom shall be amazed: the mighty men of Moah trembling shall take hold upon them: all the inhabitants of Canaan shall melt away.

lg.l: The Dukes of Edom then amaz'd,
strong Moab trembling shall
On them take hold, the Cananites
they melt away shall all.

div.p: 16 Fear and dread shall fall upon them, by the greatnes of thine arm they shall be as still as a stone, till thy people passe over,

lg.l: By greatnesse of thine arm â€¢ strong
fear, dread, shall on them fall,
They shall be still ev'n as a stone
till passe thy people all.

div.p: O Lord, till the people passe over, which thou hast purchased.

lg.l: O Lord till that the people do
passe ov're with great renown,
Which thou by thine Almighty hand
hast purchas'd as thine own.

div.p: 17 Thou shalt bring them in, and plant them in the mountain of thine inheritance, in the place O Lord, which thou hast made for thee to dwell. in.

lg.l: In hill of thine inheritance
Lord thou shalt bring them well,
And plant them in the place which thou
hast made for them to dwell.

div.p:
In the Sanctuary, O Lord, which thy hand â€¢
have established.
18 The Lord shall reign for ever and ever.

lg.l: O Lord ev'n in the Sanctuary
which thy hand stablish'd all:
The Lord for ever and also
for ever reigne he shall.

div.p: 19 For the horse of Pharaoh went in with his chariots, and with his horsemen into the sea, and the Lord brought again the waters of the sea, upon them:

lg.l: For Pharos horse with charets went
and horsmen in the sea,
The Lord again sea waters brought
upon them fearfully.

div.p: But the children of Israel went on dry land in the midst of the sea.

lg.l: But those that were the children then
of Israel by discent,
They in the midst of all the sea
on dry land safely went.

div.head: The Song of Moses a little before his death. DEUT. 32.
The Preface.
div.p: GIve ear, O ye heavens, and I will speak; and hear, O earth, the words of my mouth.

lg.l: O Ye the heavens that are high
do ye to me give ear,
The words that from my mouth proceed
O earth now do thou hear.

div.p: 2 My doctrine shall drop as the rain, my speech shall distill as the dew, as the small rain upon the tender herb, and as the showres upon the grasse.

lg.l: My doctrine as the rain shall drop,
my speach as dew shall passe,
As small rain on the tender herb,
and showrs upon the grasse.

div.p: 3 Because I will publish the name of the Lord: ascribe ye greatnesse unto our God.

lg.l: Because I surely publish will
the Name of God the Lord,
Ye greatnesse to our God therefore
ascribe with one accord.

div.head: The first Part.
div.p: 4 He is the Rock, his work is perfect: for all his wayes are judgement: a God of truth, and without iniquity, just and right is he.

lg.l: He is the rock, his work's persite,
his wayes all judgement be;
A God of truth, void of all sin,
most just and right is he.

div.p:
5 They have corrupted themselves, their spot is not the spot of his children: they are
â€¢
perverse and crooked generation.

lg.l: Their spot is not his childrens spot,
themselves corrupt'd they far,
A crooked generation
and a perverse they are.

div.p: 6 Do ye thus requite the Lord, O foolish people and unwise? is not be thy father that hath bought thee? hath he not made thee, and established thee?

lg.l: Unwise people, do ye requite
the Lord thus? Is not he
Thy father, buyer? Hath he not
made and establish'd thee?

div.p: 7 Remember the dayes of old, consider the years of many generations: ask thy father, and he will shew thee, thy elders, and they will tell thee.

lg.l: Remember ye the dayes of old,
yeers past consider well;
Thy father ask, he will thee shew,
thy Elders will thee tell.

div.p: 8 When the most high divided to the nations their inheritance, when he separated the sons of Adam,

lg.l: When the most High to Nations did
th' inheritance divide,
When he the sons of Adam all
did separate beside,

div.p: He set the bounds of the people according to the number of the children of Israel.

lg.l: He by his wisedome set the bounds
then of the people all,
According to the number of
the children of Isra'l.

div.p: 9 For the Lords portion is his people: Iacob is the lot of his inheritance.

lg.l: For to his portion hath the Lord
his people without blot:
And of his own inheritance
his Jacob is the lot.

div.p: 10 He found him in a desert land, and in the waste howling wildernesse: he led him about, he instructed him, he kept him as the apple of his eye.

lg.l: In wildernesse he found ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ , in
wast howling desert dry:
He led, instructed, and ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ kept
as th' â€¢ ple of his eye.

div.p: 11 As an eagle stirreth up her nest, fluttereth over her young, spreadeth abroad her wings, taketh them, beareth them on her wings.

lg.l: As th' Eagle stirreth up her nest,
fluttreth her young upon,
Her wings doth spread, and taketh them,
and beareth them thereon.

div.p: 12 So the Lord alone did lead him, and there was no strange god with him.

lg.l: So by his might the Lord alone
did lead him carefully,
And no strange god there was at all
with him in company.

div.p: 13 He made him ride on the high places of the earth, that he might eat the increase of the fields, and he made him to suck hony out of the rock, and oil out of the flinty rock.

lg.l: On earths high place he made him ride,
fields increase for to eat,
From flinty rocks he made him suck
the oyl and honey sweet.

div.p: 14 Butter of kine, and milk of sheep, with fat of lambs and rams of the breed of Bashan,

lg.l: Of Kine the butter, and of sheep
the milk, for them in need,
With fat of lambs, and also rams,
that were of Bashans breed.

div.p: And goats, with the fat of kidneys of wheat, and thou didst drink the pure bloud of the grape.

lg.l: He gave them goats, with Kidneys fat
of wheat that was right good,
And thou also ev'n of the grape
didst drink the purest blood.

div.head: The second Part.
div.p: 15 But Iesurun waxed fat, and kicked: thou art waxen fat, thou art grown thick,

lg.l: But Jesurun then waxed fat,
and he did also kick:
Thou waxed art exceeding fat,
thou art grown very thick,

div.p: Thou art covered with fatnesse; then he forsook God which made him, and lightly esteemed the rock of his salvation.

lg.l: With fatnesse thou art cov'rd, he then
God which him made forsook,
And he of his salvations rock
light estimation took.

div.p: 16 They provocked him to jealousie with strange gods, with abominations provoked they him to anger.

lg.l: They him provok'd to jealousie
with strange gods evry way,
Him with abominations
to wrath provoked they.
To dev'ls not God they sacrific'd,
to gods whom they not knew,
New gods whom not your fathers fear'd,
that were come up of new.

div.p: 18 Of the rock that begat thee thou art unmindfull, and hast forgotten God that formed thee.

lg.l: Thou art unmindfull of the rock
which once thee did beget,
And God himself that formed thee
thou likewise didst forget.

div.head: The third Part.
div.p: 19 And when the Lord saw it, he abhorred them, because of the provocking of his sons, and of his daughters.

lg.l: And when the Lord it saw, he did
abhor them evry one,
Because of the provoking great
of daughter and of son.

div.p: 20 And he said, I will hide my face from them, I will see what their end shall be: for they are a very froward generation, children in whom is no faith.

lg.l: He said, I'le hide from them my face,
and I their end will see:
For they a very froward race,
and faithlesse children be.

div.p: 21 They have moved me to jealousie with that which is not God, they have provoked me to anger with their vanities:

lg.l: With that which is not God they have
me mov'd to jealousie,
To anger they have me provok'd,
ev'n with their vanitie.

div.p: And I will move them to jealousie with those which are not a people, I will provoke them to anger with a foolish nation.

lg.l: And I'le them move to jealousie
with such as are no flock,
Them with a foolish nation
to anger I'le provoke.

div.p: 22 For a fire is kindled in my anger, and shall burn unto the lowest hell, and shall consume the earth with her increase, and set on fire the foundations of the mountains.

lg.l: For fire is kindled in my wrath,
it burns to lowest hell,
Earths increase, hills foundations
consum â€¢ and fire it shall.

div.p: 23 I will heap mischiefs upon them, I will spend mine arrows upon them.

lg.l: Upon them likewise great mischiefes
most surely heap I will,
And in mine anger I will spend
on them mine arrows ill.

div.p: 24 They shall be burnt with hunger, and devoured with burning heat, and with bitter destruction:

lg.l: They shall be altogether burnt
with pain of hunger great,
And with destruction bitter als
devour'd with burning heat:

div.p: I will also send the teeth of beasts upon them, with the poyson of serpents of the dust.

lg.l: I also will the teeth of beasts
upon them fiercely thrust,
Ev'n with the poison that is of
the serpents of the dust.

div.p: 25 The sword without, and terrour within, shall destroy both the young man and the virgin, the suckling also with the man of gray hairs.

lg.l: The sword without, terrour within,
the young man shall destroy,
The virgin, and the suckling als
with him whose haires are gray.

div.p: 26 I said, I would s â€¢ atter them into corners, I would make the remembrance of them to cease from among men:

lg.l: I said, that into corners I
would them all scatter then,
I would make their remembrance als
to cease from among men:

div.p: 27 Were it not that I feared the wrath of the enemy, lest their adversaries should behave themselves strang â€¢ ly,

lg.l: Yea were it not I fear'd the wrath
of th' enemy they have,
And lest that their adversaries
should strangely them behave,

div.p: And lest they should say, Our hand is high, and the Lord hath not done all this.

lg.l: And lest that they with hauty heart
should say these words anone:
Our hand now high is, and the Lord
this work all hath not done.

div.p: 28 For they are a nation void of counsell, neither is there any understanding in them.
29 O that they were wise, that they understood this, that they would consider their latter end.

lg.l: For of counsell a Nation void
they are, nothing know they,
O that they wise this understood,
and their last end would weigh.

div.p: 30 How should one chase a thousand, and two put ten thousand to flight, except their Rock had sold them, and the Lord had shut them up?

lg.l: How should but one a thousand chase,
and two chase thousands ten:
â€¢ xcept their Rock thus had them sold,
and them shut up had then.

div.p:
31 For their rock is not as our Rock, even
â€¢ ur enemies themselves being judges.

lg.l: For in no way the rock that's theirs
as our Rock mighty is,
Our enemies themselves they are
the judges ev'n of this.

div.p:
32 For their vine is of the vine of Sodom â€¢â€¢ nd of the fields of Gomorrah: their grapes are
â€¢â€¢ apes of gall, their clusters are bitter.

lg.head: â€¢ 2
lg.l: Of Sodoms vine and Gomors fields,
their vine is surely all,
Their clusters they most bitter are,
their grapes are grapes of gall.

div.p:
33 Their wine is the poison of dragons, and
â€¢ he cruell venime of aspes.

34 Is not this laid up in store with me, and
â€¢ aled up among my treasures?

lg.head: â€¢ 3
lg.l: Their wine of dragons poison is,
of asps the venim strong:

lg.head: â€¢ 4
lg.l: 4 Is not this laid in store with me
my treasures seal'd among?

div.head: The fourth Part.
div.p:
35 To me belongeth vengeance, and re
â€¢ mpence, their foot shall slide in due time:

lg.l: Vengeance to me and recompence
belongeth for their crime:
Their foot shall slide assuredly
in due appointed time.

div.p: For the day of their calamity is at hand, and the things that shall come upon them make haste.

lg.l: The day of their calamity
it is now near at hand,
And things that shall upon them come
make hast, and shall not stand.

div.p: 36 For the Lord shall judge his people, and repent himself for his servants; when he seeth that their power is gone, and there is none shut up, or left.

lg.l: For God shall his own people judge,
and for his saints repent,
When none shut up or left he sees
but that their power is spent.

div.p: 37 And he shall say, where are their gods, their rock in whom they trusted.

lg.l: And he in his great wrath shall say,
where are their gods now gone?
Their stable rock in whom they all
did put their trust alone.

div.p: 38 Which did eat the fat of their sacrifices, and drank the wine of their drink-offerings? let them rise up and help you, and be your protection.

lg.l: Which fat ate of their sacrifice,
and drank drink offrings wine:
Let them rise up now and you help,
as your protection fine.

div.p: 39 See now that I, even I am he, and there is no god with me: I kill, and I make alive; I wound, and I heal:

lg.l: See now that I am he, ev'n I,
no god there is with me:
I kill, and make alive; I wound,
and als make whole to be.

div.p: Neither is there any that can deliver out of my hand.
40 For I lift up my hand to heaven, and say, I live for ever.

lg.l: Nor is there any now that can
out of my hand deliver:
For I lift up my hand to heaven,
and say, I live for ever.

div.p: 41 If I whet my glittering sword, and mine hand take hold on judgement; I will render vengeance to mine enemies, and will reward them that hate me.

lg.l: If hold my hand on judgement take,
and glittring sword I whet,
I'le render vengeance to my foes,
and pay those that me hate.

div.p:
42 I will make mine arrows drunk wit â€¢
blood (and my sword shall devour flesh)

lg.l: I also those mine arrows will
make drunk with blood therefore,
The flesh of all mine enemies
my sword it shall devore.

div.p:
And that with the blood of the slain, and o â€¢
the captives, from the beginning of revenges upo â€¢
the enemy.

lg.l: With blood of those that have been slain
and those that captives lyâ–ª
From the beginning of revenge
upon the enemy.

div.p: 43 Rejoice, O ye nations with his peopleâ–ª for he will avenge the bloud of his servants,

lg.l: Rejoice ye nations with his folk,
for he who doth not change,
Will of his servants all the blood
in his own time avenge.

div.p: And will render vengeance to his adversaries, and will be mercifull unto his land, and to his people.

lg.l: And will to his adversaries
a vengeance render full,
And to his people and his land
he will be mercifull.

div.head: The Song of Deborah, and Barak, after the victory against the army of Iabin King of Canaan; who reigned in Hazor, whose captaine was Sisera, whose head was cut off by Iahell, the wi â€¢ e of Heber. JUDGES 5. vers. 2.
div.p: PRaise ye the LORD for the avenging of Israel, when the people willingly offered themselves:

lg.l: FOr the avenging of Isra â€¢ l
praise ye the Lord most hy,
When as the people offered
themselves most willingly.

div.p: 3 Hear, O ye kings, give ear, O ye princes; I, even I will â€¢ ing unto the Lord, I will sing praise to the Lord God of Israel.

lg.l: Hear Oye Kings, ye Princes als
give ear, I, ev'n I will
Sing to the Lord, to Israels God
I will sing praises still.

div.p: 4 Lord when thou wentedst out of Seir, when thou marchedst out of the field of Edom, the earth trembled, and the heavens dropped, the clouds also dropped water.

lg.l: Lord when thou wentest out of Seir,
and march'd from Edom field,
The earth did tremble, heav'ns did drop,
the clouds did water yeeld.

div.p: 5 The mountaines melted from before the Lord, even that Sinai from before the Lord God of Israel.

lg.l: The mountains melted from before
the Lord God Eternall,
Ev'n that Sinai from God before,
the God of Israel.

div.p: 6 In the dayes of Shamgar the son of Anath, in the dayes of Iael, the high-wayes were unoccupied, and the travellers walked through bywayes.

lg.l: In dayes of Shamgar Anaths son
of Jael in the dayes,
The high wayes were unoccupi'd
men travell'd through bywayes.

div.p: 7 The inhabitants of the villages ceased, they ceased in Israel, untill that I â€¢ Deborah arose that I arose a mother in Israel.

lg.l: They ceas'd that dwelt in villages,
in Israel they did cease,
Till I Deborah in Isra'l
a mother rose for peace.

div.p: 8 They chose new gods; then was war in the gates: was there a shield or spear seen among fourty thousand in Israel?

lg.l: They chose new gods, war seizd their gates
was there a shield or spear?
That fourty thousand men among
in Israel did appear.

div.p:
9 My heart is toward the Governours of
â€¢ rael, that offered themselves willingly among
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ people: Blesse ye the Lord.

lg.l: My heart's to Israels governours
who t'offer did accord
Themselves 'mong people willingly,
O do ye blesse the Lord.

div.p:
10 Speak ye that ride on white asses, ye that
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ in judgement, and walk by the way.

lg.head: â€¢ 0
lg.l: â€¢ 0 Ye that do ride on asses white
do ye together say;
â€¢ e that do in the judgement sit
and walk als by the way.

div.p:
11 They that are delivered from the noise
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ archers in the places of drawing water, there â€¢ all they rehearse the righteous acts of the Lord,

lg.head: â€¢ 1
lg.l: Who sav'd are from the archers noise
where they did water draw,
â€¢ here shall they of the Lord rehearse
the righteous acts and law.

div.p:
Even the righteous acts towards the inha
â€¢ itants of his villages in Israel: then shall the â€¢â€¢ ople of the Lord go down to the gates.
ã€ˆ1 page duplicateã€‰
ã€ˆ1 page duplicateã€‰

lg.l: The righteous acts in Israel
in villages there done:
Then shall the people of the Lord
unto the gates go down.

div.p: 12 Awake, awake, Deborah: awake, awake utter a song, ariso Barak, and lead thy captivi â€¢ captive, thou son of Abinoam.

lg.l: Wake, wake, wake, wake, Deborah sing â€¢
thou Barak rise anone,
Thy captive lead captivity
thou Abinoams son.

div.p:
13 Then he made him that remaineth hav â€¢
dominion over the nobles among the people: th â€¢
Lord made me have dominion over the mighty.

lg.l: Him that remains dominion â€¢ then
he ov'r the Nobles gave
'Mong people; God dominion made
me ov'r the mighty have.

div.p:
14 Out of Ephraim was there a root
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ them against Amalek, after thee Benjamin, amon â€¢
thy people:

lg.l: Of Ephraim 'gainst Amalek
there was a worthy root:
And after thee, was Benjamin,
among thy people great.

div.p:
Out of Machir came down governours, an â€¢
out of Zebulun they that handle the pen of ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
writer.

lg.l: And out of Machir als came down
thy Governours, and then
They did come out of Zebulon
that handle writers pen.

div.p: 15 And the princes of Issachar were with Deborah: even Issachar,

lg.l: And the most mighie Princes there
of Issachar that day,
Were with Deborah in the field,
ev'n Issachar I say,

div.p:
And also Barak, he was sent on foot into the
â€¢ alley: for the divisions of Reuben, there were
â€¢ reat thoughts of heart.

lg.l: Als Barack to the valley sent
on foot, did soon depart:
For Reuben his divisions
thee were great thoughts of heart.

div.p:
16 Why abodest thou among the sheep folds,
â€¢ o hear the bleatings of the flocks? for the divisions of Reuben, there were great searchings of heart.

lg.l: Why in sheep folds abodest thou
to hear flocks bleet apart?
For Reuben his divisions
were searchings great of heart.

div.p: 17 Gilead abode beyond Iordan: and why did Dan remain in ships? Asher continued on the sea shore, and abode in his breaches.

lg.l: Beyond the Jordan Gilead 'bod,
why Dan in ships remain'd;
Asher continu'd on sea shore,
within his breaches train'd,

div.p: 18 Zebulun and Naphtali were a people that jeoparded their lives unto the death, in the high places of the field.

lg.l: Then Zebulon and Naphtali
were people that did yeeld
Their lives to jeopard unto death,
in high parts of the field,

div.p:
19 The kings came and fought, then fough â€¢
the kings of Canaan in Taanach by the water â€¢
of Megiddo, they took no gain of money.

lg.l: Kings came and fought, in Taanah fough â€¢
the Kings of Canaan then
They by Megiddos waters fought,
of money took no gain.

div.p:
20 They fought from heaven, the stars i â€¢
their courses fought against Sisera.

lg.l: Together against Sisera
they fought from heavens hy,
The Stars als in their courses all
did fight then by and by.

div.p:
21 The river of Kishon swept them away, th â€¢
ancient river, the river Kishon: O my sou â€¢
thou hast troden down strength.

lg.l: The river Kishon, Kishon old
away them sweept eachone,
O thou my soul thou surely hast,
great strength now troden down.

div.p:
22 Then were the horse hoofs broken, by
â€¢ he meanes of the pransings, the pransings of
â€¢ heir mighty ones.

lg.l: Then were the hoofs of horses strong
all broken with their bones,
Ev'n by the meanes of pransings â€¢ great,
pransings of mighty ones.

div.p: 23 Curse ye Meroz, (said the angel of the Lord) curse ye bitterly the inhabitants thereof:

lg.head: â€¢ 3
lg.l: Curse ye the men of Meros all,
said th' Angel of the Lord:
Curse ye th'inhabitans thereof
most bitterly by word;

div.p:
Because they came not to the help of the Lord,
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ the help of the Lord against the mighty.

lg.l: Because that they came not all
their help for to afford
â€¢ nto the Lord, 'gainst mighty men
they did not help the Lord.

div.p:
24 Blessed above women shall Iael the wise
â€¢ f Heber the Kenite be, blessed shall she be above women in the tent.

lg.l: Jael of Heber Kenite wife
'bove women blest shall be,
Above all women in the tent
a blessing shall she see.

div.p: 25 He asked water, and she gave him milk she brought forth butter in a lordly dish.

lg.l: He water asked, and she gave
him milk of sweet relish,
She also to him butter brought
forth in a lordly dish.

div.p:
26 She put her hand to the nail, and h â€¢
right hand to the workmens hammer: and wi â€¢â€¢
the hammer she smot Sisera,

lg.l: Her right hand to the hammer there
unto the nail she put
Her hand, and with the hammer then
there Sisera she smotâ–ª

div.p: She smot of his head, when she had pierce and stricken through his temples.

lg.l: When she th â€¢â€¢ through his temples both
had stricken in great speed,
And pierced him, thereafter she
did there smite off his head.

div.p:
27 At her feet he bowed, he sell, he ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
down: at her feet he bowed, he fell; where ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
bowed, there he fell down dead.

lg.l: He at her feet did bow, he fell,
and he lay down anone,
He at her feet bow'd, fell, where bow'd,
there he ev'n dead fell down.

div.p: 28 The mother of Sisera looked out at a window, and cried through the lattesse, why is his chariot so long in coming?

lg.l: Then Sis'ras mother looked out
at windows, and did cry
Through lattesse, what can be the cause
his charets thus do stay?

div.p: Why tary the wheels of his chariots?
29 Her wise ladies answered her, yea, she returned answer to her self,

lg.l: Why tary thus his charet wheels?
Her ladies wise did say,
Yea she unto her self return'd
an answer on this way,

div.p: 30 Have they not sped? have they not divided the prey, to every man a damsell or two?

lg.l: Have they not sped? and have they not
the wealthy prey also
Divided unto evry man
a damosell or two?

div.p: To Sisera a prey of divers colours, a prey of divers colours of needle work,

lg.l: To Sisera a prey that they
of diverse colours make,
Of diverse colours ev'n a prey
that is of needle work.

div.p: Of divers colours of needle-work on both sides, meet for the necks of them that take the spoil?

lg.l: Of diverse colours on both sides
of needle work they make,
Which for the neck of them is meet,
that thus the spoile do take.

div.p: 31 So let all thine enemies perish, O Lord but let them that love him, be as the sun when he goeth forth in his might.

lg.l: Lord let thy foes so perish all;
but who him love upright,
Let them be as the Sun, when as
he forth goth in his might.

div.head: The Song of Hannah, which she sang to God when she had born Samuel, after long barre â€¢ nesse. 1 SAM. 2. vers. 1.
div.p: MY heart rejoiceth in the Lord, mine horn is exalted in the Lord, my mouth is enlarged over mine enemies: because I rejoice in thy salvotion.

lg.l: MY heart in God doth joy, in God
my horn's rais'd: ov're my foes
My mouth inlarged is, for I
do in thy health rejoice.

div.p: 2 There is none holy as the Lord: for there is none beside thee: neither is there any rock like our God.

lg.l: There is none holy as the Lord,
for none is thee beside:
Nor is there any rock that doth
like to our God abide.

div.p: 3 Talk no more so exceeding proudly, let not arrogancie come out of your mouth:

lg.l: See that henceforth ye do no more
exceeding proudly talk,
Nor let your tongue within your mouth
with arrogancy wall â€¢ .

div.p: For the Lord is a God of knowledge, and by him actions are weighed.

lg.l: Because the Lord he is a Godâ–ª
of knowledge as we see,
And by him in a ballance just
all actions weighed be.

div.p: 4 The bows of the mighty men are broken, and they that stumbled, are girt with strength.

lg.l: The bows ev'n of the mighty men
are broken all at length,
And they that stumbled here and there
are well now girt with strength.

div.p:
5 They that were full, have hired out themselves for bread, and they that were hungry,
â€¢ eased:

lg.l: They that very full now have
hir'd out themselves for bread,
And they that also hungry were,
did cease from having need:

div.p: So that the barren hath born seven, and she that hath many children, is waxed feeble.

lg.l: So that she that still barren was,
hath born sev'n great and small,
And she that many children hath
is waxed feeble all.

div.p:
6 The Lord killeth, and maketh alive, ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
bringeth down to the grave, and bringeth up.

lg.l: The Lord almighty doth both kill
and als alive doth save,
He bringeth up, and likewise he
brings down unto the grave.

div.p:
7 The Lord maketh poor, and maketh ri â€¢â€¢
he bringeth low, and lifteth up.

lg.l: The Lord is he that maketh poore
and also maketh rich,
He bringeth very low, and he
up lifteth to a pitch.

div.p:
8 He raiseth up the poor out of the dust, an â€¢
lifteth up the begger from the dunghill, to se â€¢
them among princes,

lg.l: He raiseth from the dust the poore,
the begger from dunghillâ–ª
He lifteth up, them for to set
among the Princes still.

div.p:
And to make them inherit the throne of glory:
â€¢â€¢ r the pillars of the earth are the Lords, and ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
hath set the world upon them.

lg.l: Of glorys Throne to make them heires,
for that the Lords alone
Of earth the pillars are, and he
the world set them upon.

div.p:
9 He will keep the feet of his saints, and the
â€¢ icked shall bee silent in darknesse; for by
â€¢â€¢ ength shall no man prevail.

lg.l: He of his saints will keep the feet,
the wicked all at length
â€¢ dark shall silent be, for none
prevaile shall by his strength.

div.p:
10 The adversaries of the Lord shall be bro
â€¢â€¢ n to pieces: out of heaven shall he thunder
â€¢â€¢ no them:

lg.l: The Lords adversaries they shall
in pieces broken be,
â€¢ ut of the heaven upon them
a thundring make shall he.

div.p:
The Lord shall judge the ends of the earth,
â€¢â€¢ d he shall give strength unto his king, and ex
â€¢â€¢
he horn of his anointed.

lg.l: Ends of the earth the Lord shall judge,
and strength give to his King,
The horn of his Anointed One
he shall exalt to reign.

div.head: The lamentations of David for the death of Saul and Ionathan, slaine upon the mountain of Gilboah.
div.p:
THe beauty of Israel is slain upon thy hi â€¢
places: how are the mighty fallen.

lg.l: OF Israel is the beauty slain
upon thy places hy,
How is it that thy mighty men
are fallen shamefully!

div.p:
2 Tell it not in Gath, publish it not in ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
streets of Askelon: lest the daughters of ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
Philistines rejoice, lest the daughters of the ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
circumcised triumph.

lg.l: Tell't not in Gath nor Askelon,
lest Philistines rejoice,
Lest daughters of th' uncircumcisde
triumph with shouting voice.

div.p:
3 Ye mountains of Gilboa, let there be
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
dew, neither let there be rain upon you, nor fiel â€¢
of offerings:

lg.l: Ye of Gilboah mountains high
O let there be no dew,
Let neither fields of offerings,
nor rain be upon you,

div.p: For there the shield of the mighty is vilely cast away, the shield of Saul, as though he had not been anointed with oil.

lg.l: For of the mighty is the shield,
there cast away as vile,
The shield of Saul as he had not,
anointed been with oil.

div.p: 4 From the bloud of the slain, from the fat of the mighty, the bow of Ionathan turned not back, and the sword of Saul returned not empty.

lg.l: From bloud of slain, from mighties fate
the bow of Jonathan
Did not turn back, the sword of Saul
return'd not empty than.

div.p: 5 Saul and Ionathan were lovely and pleasant in their lives, and in their death they were not divided.

lg.l: Saul, Jonathan, both lovely were
and pleasant in their lives,
And in their death at last they not
divided were likewise.

div.p: They were swifter then eagles, they were stronger then lions.

lg.l: Then Eagles that are swift in flight
they were both swifter far,
Yea they both stronger were also
then fiercest lions are.

div.p: 6 Ye daughters of Israel weep over Saul, who clothed you in scarlet, with other delights, who put on ornaments of gold upon your apparell.

lg.l: Ye Israels daughters, weep ov'r Saul
who with delights eachone
In scarlet cloth'd, who ornaments
of gold your clothes put on.

div.p: 7 How are the mighty fallen in the midst of the battell! O Ionathan, thou wast slaine in thine bigh places.

lg.l: How in midst of the battell do
the mighty fallen ly!
O Jonathan thou wast ev'n slain
upon thy places hy.

div.p: 8 I am distressed for thee, my brother Ionathan: very pleasant hast thou been unto me:

lg.l: My brother Jonathan, I am
distressed â€¢ ore for thee,
For very pleasant thou hast been
at all times unto me:

div.p: Thy love to me was wonderfull, passing the love of women.
9 How are the mighty fallen, and the weapons of war perished.

lg.l: Thy love to me was wonderfull,
all womens love it past:
How fell the mighty, and of warre
were all the weapons lost!

div.head: The Song of David, which he sang to give thanks after that Nathan had promised him benefits and blessings, but chiefly the Messias to come of his seed. 2 SAM. 7. vers. 18.
div.p: WHo am I, O Lord God? and what is my house, that thou hast brought mee hitherto?

lg.l: O Lord my God, now who am I
that thou on me hast thought?
What is my house that thou in love
me hitherto hast brought?

div.p: 2 And this was yet a small thing in thy sight, O Lord God; but thou hast spoken also of thy servants house for a great while to come,

lg.l: And this O Lord God in thy sight,
a small thing was in summe;
But of thy servants house thou spak'st
for a great while to come.

div.p: And is this the manner of man, O Lord God?
3 And what can David say more unto thee? for thou, Lord God, knowest thy servant.

lg.l: Lord God, is this the maner of man?
What David more thee to
Can say? for thou O Lord my God
dost me thy servant kno.

div.p: 4 For thy words sake, and according to thine own heart hast thou done all these great things; to make thy servant know them.

lg.l: For thy words sake, according to
thine own heart hast thou done
All those great things, for them to make
unto thy servant known.

div.p: 5 Wherefore thou art great, O Lord God: for there is none like thee, neither is there any god beside thee, according to all that we have heard with our ears.

lg.l: Thou Lord art great, like thee is none,
no God is thee beside,
According to all things that wee
with our own ears have tri'd.

div.p: 6 And what one nation in the earth is like thy people, even like Israel, whom God went to redeem for a people to himself,

lg.l: And what one Nation in the earth
doth like thy people seem,
Like Israel whom to himself,
God went for to redeem,

div.p: And to make him a name, and to do for you great things, and terrible for thy land,

lg.l: Ev'n for a people, and a Name
to make him, and to do
For you great things and terrible,
for this thy land also,

div.p: Before thy people which thou redeemdst to thee from Egypt, from the nations and their gods?

lg.l: Before thy people which thou hastâ–ª
redeemed unto thee
From Egypt, from the Nations,
and these their gods that be.

div.p:
7 For thou hast confirmed to thy self thy people Israel to be a people unto thee for ever â€¢
and thou, Lord, art become their God.

lg.l: For to thy self thou Isra'l hast
confirm'd to thee for ay
A people; and thou art, O Lord,
become their God alway.

div.p: 8 And now, O Lord God, the word that thou hast spoken concerning thy servant, and concerning his house, establish it for ever, and do as thou hast said.

lg.l: What of thy servant and his house
thou Lord hast spoken now,
Do as thou saidst, and so for ay
establish it do thou.

div.p:
9 And let thy name be magnified for ever,
saying; The Lord of hosts is the God over Israel:

lg.l: And let thy Name that's glorious
be magnifi'd for ay,
The Lord of hosts he is the God
that's over Israel, say;

div.p: And let the house of thy servant David hee established before thee.
10 For thou, O Lord of hosts, God of Israel, hast revealed to thy servant,

lg.l: Let Davids house thy servant be
before thee stablish'd well:
Thou Lord of hosts, Israls God didst
to thy servant reveal:

div.p: Saying, I will build thee an house: therefore hath thy servant found in his heart to pray this prayer unto thee.

lg.l: Thou said'st I will thee build an house,
therefore thy servant hee
Hath in his heart found for to pray
this prayer unto thee.

div.p: 11 And now, O Lord God, thou art that God, and thy words he true, and thou hast promised this goodnesse unto thy servant.

lg.l: And now, O Lord, that God thou art,
thy words are very true,
And thou this goodnesse promisde hast
unto thy servant now.
Therefore be pleased for to blesse
thy servants house alway,
That it may so continue still
before thee fast for ay.

div.p: For thou O Lord God, hast spoken it, and with thy blessing let the house of thy servant be blessed for ever.

lg.l: For thou Lord God hast spoken it,
with blessings come from thee
O do thou let thy servants house
for ever blessed be.

div.head: The Song of Isaiah, concerning the vineyard, wherein Gods people is reproved for their barrennesse in good works, notwithstanding of all the paines were taken by the Prophets. ISAIAHâ–ª 5. vers. 1.
div.p: NOw will I sing to my welbeloved, a song, of my beloved touching his vineyard: my welbeloved hath a vineyard in a very fruitfull hill.

lg.l: TO my Beloved of his vine
a song now sing I will:
My Welbelov'd a vineyard hath
in a most fruitfull hill.

div.p: 2 And he fenced it, and gathered out the stones thereof, and planted it with the choicest vine, and bult a tower in the midst of it.

lg.l: He did it fence, and gathered out
the stones thereof eachone,
He planted it with choicest vine,
a tower he built thereon.

div.p: And also made a wine-presse therein: and he looked that it should bring forth grapes, and it brought forth wilde grapes.

lg.l: Hee a vine-presse made als therein,
and look'd it should bring forth
Good grapes, but forth at last it brought
wild grapes of nothing worth.

div.p:
3 And now; O inhabitants of Ierusalem, and men of Iudah, judge, I pray you, betwix â€¢
me and my vineyard.

lg.l: And now, O ye inhabitants
of Salem, and als ye
Of Judah men, judge, I you pray,
'twixt my vineyard and me.

div.p: 4 What could have been done more to my vineyard, that I have not done in it? wherefore when I looked that it should bring forth grapes, brought it forth wilde grapes?

lg.l: What could I my vineyard unto
do more then I have done?
Wherefore when for good grapes I look'd,
did wild grapes grow thereon?

div.p: 5 And now go to; I will tell you what I will do to my vineyard, I will take away the hedge thereof, and it shall be eaten up:

lg.l: And now go to; I'le tell you what
I'le to my vineyard do,
I'le take away its hedge, and it
shall be up eaten so:

div.p: And break down the wall thereof, and it shall be troden down.
6 And I will lay it waste: it shall not bee pruned, nor digged,

lg.l: And I'le break down the wall thereof,
and it trode down shall be:
I'le lay it wast, none pruned shall
nor yet it digged see,

div.p: But there shall come up briers and thorns: I will also command the clouds that they rain no rain upon it.

lg.l: But briars and thornes there shall come up:
I also will anone
Command the clouds that they no rain
shall rain the same upon.

div.p: 7 For the vineyard of the Lord of hoasts is the house of Israel, and the men of Iudah his pleasant plant.

lg.l: For vineyard of the Lord of hosts
the house of Israel is,
The men of Judah also are
the plasant plant of his.

div.p: And he looked for judgement, but behold oppression; for righteousnesse, but behold a cry.

lg.l: And he did then for judgement look,
but lo oppression hard;
For rigtheousnesse, but O behold,
a cry then there was heard.

div.head: A Song of thanks for the mercies of God. ISA. 12. vers. 1.
div.p: O Lord, I will praise thee, though thou wast angry with me, thine anger is turned away, and thou comfortedst me.

lg.l: I Will thee praise, O Lord, though thou
with me most angry wast,
Thine anger turned is away,
thou me comforted hast.

div.p: 2 Behold, God is my salvation: I will trust, and not be afraid; for the Lord IEHOVAH is my strength and my song, be also is become my salvation.

lg.l: Behold, God's my salvation.
I'le trust, and will not fear â€¢
For Lord Jovah's my strength and song,
he's my salvation near.

div.p:
3 Therefore with joy shall ye draw water
â€¢ t of the wells of salvation.
4 And in that day shall ye say,

lg.l: Therefore yee of salvation,
with joy shall in that day,
Out of the wells draw water als,
Ye in that day shall say,

div.p:
Praise the Lord, call upon his name, declare
â€¢ is doings among the people, make mention that
â€¢ is name is exalted.

lg.l: Praise ye the Lordâ–ª call on his Name,
the doings that are his
Shew to his people, mention make
that's Name exalted is.

div.p: 5 Sing unto the Lord; for he hath done excellent things: this is known in all the earth.

lg.l: Do ye now sing unto the Lord;
because that he hath done
The things that be most excellent;
this in all earth is known.

div.p: 6 Cry out and shout, thou inhabitant of Zion: for great is the holy one of Israel in the midst of thee.

lg.l: Of Zion thou inhabitant,
cry out, and shouting be:
For of Isra â€¢ l the holy One
is great in midst of thee,

div.head: A Song inciting to confidence in GOD. Isa. 26. vers. 1.
div.p: WE have a strong city, salvation will God appoint for wals and bulwarks.

lg.l: WEE have a city that is strong,
the Lord salvation so
Hee will appoint for mighty wals
and bulwarks strong also.

div.p: 2 Open ye the gates, that the righteous nation which keepeth the truth may enter in.

lg.l: Open ye the gates, that so
the righteous Nation
Which constantly the trueth doth keep
may enter in anone.

div.p: 3 Thou wilt keep him in perfect peace, whose minde is stayed on thee: because he trusteth in thee.

lg.l: Assuredly thou wilt him keep
in perfect peace to be,
Whose minde is still upon thee staid, because he trusts in thee.

div.p: 4 Trust ye in the Lord for ever: for in the Lord IEHOVAH is everlasting strength.

lg.l: For ever trust ye in the Lord,
for ye shal feel at length,
That in the Lord JEHOVAH is
an everlasting strength.

div.p:
5 For he bringeth down them that dwell on
â€¢ igh, the loftie city he layeth it low, he layeth it
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ , even to the ground, he bringeth it even to
â€¢ e dust.

lg.l: For dwellers high he doth bring down,
the city proud layes low,
He layes it low, to ground it brings
ev'n to the dust below.

div.p:
6 The foot shall tread it down, even the feet
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ the poore, and the steps of the needy.
7 The way of the just is uprightnesse: thou ost upright, dost weight the path of the just.

lg.l: The foot, poores feet and needies steps
shall tread it in the way:
Upright's the justs way, thou upright,
the just mans path dost weigh.

div.p:
8 Yea in the way of thy judgements, O Lord,
â€¢ ve we waited for thee; the desire of our soul to thy name, and to the remembrance of thee.

lg.l: Yea in thy judgements way, O Lord,
we waited have for thee,
â€¢ ur soules desires unto thy Name,
and thy remembrance be.

div.p:
9 With my soul have I desired thee in the
â€¢ ght, yea with my spirit within me will I seek
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ early.
