lg.l: I with my soul desired have
thee in the time of hight,
Yea with my spirit within me I
will seek thee early right:

div.p: For when thy judgments are in the earth the inhabitants of the world will learn righteousnesse.

lg.l: For when the judgements that thou sends
upon the earth do presse,
Then all the worlds inhabitants
will learn thy righteousnesse.

div.p:
10 Let favour be shewed to the wicked, y â€¢
will he not learn righteousnesse:

lg.l: Let unto him that wicked is
be favour shew'd not small,
Yet for the same he righteousnesse
will not then learn at all:

div.p:
In the land of uprightnesse will he deal unjustly, and will not behold the majesty of ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
LORD.

lg.l: Ev'n in the land of uprightnesse
he will unjustly deal,
And of the Lord the Majesty
behold no way he will.
Lord, when thy hand is lifted up,
they will not see; but they
Shall see, and be asham'd, because
the people they envy.

div.p: Yea the fire of thine enemies shall devour them.

12 Lord, thou wilt ordain peace for us: for
â€¢ hou also hast wrought all our works in us.
div.l: Yea them thy foes fire shall devore,

lg.l: Lord thou wilt ordain thus
Firm peace for us, for thou als hast
wrought all our works in us.

div.p:
13 O Lord our God, other lords besides
â€¢ eo have had dominion over us: but by thee
â€¢ nly will we make mention of thy name.

lg.head: â€¢ 3
lg.l: â€¢ 3 Lord God, besides thee other gods
ov'r us dominion had:
We'd only of thy Name, by thee
will mention to be made.

div.p:
14 They are dead, they shall not live; they
â€¢ re deceased, they shall not rise:

lg.l: Henceforth these wicked shall not live
who are now dead and slain,
â€¢ t last they all deceased are,
they shal not rise again.

div.p:
Therefore hast thou visited and destroyed
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ , and made all their memorie to perish.

lg.l: Therefore thou hast them visited,
and them destroyd alway,
â€¢ nd als hast made their memorie
to perish quite away.

div.p:
15 Thou hast increased the nation, O Lor â€¢
thou hast increased the nation, thou art glorified thou hadst removed it far unto all the ends of th â€¢
earth.

lg.l: Thou hast increas'd the nation, Lord
thou hast increas'd its worth,
Thou'rt glorifi'd; thou it remov'd
farre to all ends of earth.

div.p:
16 Lord, in trouble have they visited thee, th â€¢
poured out a prayer when thy chastening wa â€¢
upon them.

lg.l: Lord, when they were in trouble they
did visite thee anone,
They prayers powred out when was
thy chastning them upon.

div.p:
17 Like as a woman with childe that draweth near the time of her delivery, is in pain, an â€¢
cryeth out in her pangs; so have we been in th â€¢
sight, O Lord.

lg.l: As she that is with child drawes near
to her deliverie;
In pain is, and cryes in her pangs,
so in thy sight were we.

div.p:
18 We have been with childe, we have bee â€¢
in pain, we have as it were brought forth wind

lg.l: We surely all have been with child,
we in great pain of mind
Have all been, we have as it were
brought forth the very wind:

div.p:
We have not wrought any deliverance in the
â€¢ rth, neither have the inhabitants of the world
â€¢ llen.

lg.l: â€¢ e have not a deliverance wrought
on earth, as we perceive,
â€¢ or yet the worlds inhabitants
at all down fallen have.

div.p: 19 Thy dead men shall live, together with dead body shall they arise:

lg.l: Thy men that dead are they shall live
together well they all
â€¢ ith my dead bodie ev'n revive,
and als arise they shall:

div.p:
Awake and sing ye that dwell in dust: for thy
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
is as the dew of herbs, and the earth shall
â€¢ out the dead.

lg.l: â€¢ ake, sing ye in dust that dwell,
as dew of herbes indeed
is thy dew, and als the earth
shall cast out all her dead.

div.p:
Come, my people, enter thou into thy cham
â€¢â€¢â€¢ s, and shut thy doores about thee: hide thy
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ as it were for a little moment, untill the
â€¢ ignation be overpast.

lg.l: My people, to thy chambers come
doors shut about thee fast,
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ thou thee for a moment hide,
till wrath be overpast.

div.p: 21 For behold, the Lord cometh out of his place to punish the inhabitants of the earth for their iniquitie:

lg.l: For lo, the Lord out of his place
doth come most speedilie
To punish earths inhabitants,
for their iniquitie.

div.p: The earth also shall disclose her bloud, and shall no more cover her slain.

lg.l: The earth shall als disclose the blood,
that in it did remain,
And shall no more the means afford,
to cover close her slain.

div.head: The Song of Hezekiah, after God had healed him of his sicknesse. &c. ISA. 38. vers. 10.
div.p:
I Said in the cutting off of my dayes, I shall g â€¢
to the gates of the grave: I am deprived o â€¢
the residue of my years.

lg.l: IN cutting off my dayes I said,
to gates of grave I'le go:
Of those my yeers the residue
I am deprived so.

div.p:
2 I said, I shall not see the Lord, even th â€¢
Lord in the land of the living: I shall behold man no more with the inhabitants of the world,

lg.l: In livings land the Lord, the Lord,
I said, I shall not see:
I shall no more see man with those
on earth that dwellers be.

div.p: 3 Mine age is departed, and is removed from me, as a shepheards tent: I have cut off like a weaver my life:

lg.l: Departed is mine age, and is
remov'd from me with strife
As shepherds tents; I weaver like
have thus cut off my life.

div.p: He will cut me of with pining sicknesse: from day even to night wilt thou make an end of me.

lg.l: That I may wholly be cut off,
hee'le pining sicknesse send,
From day ev'n unto night wilt thou
so of me make an end.

div.p:
4 I reckoned till monrning, that as a lion so will he break all my bones: from day even to
â€¢ ight wilt thou make an end of me.

lg.l: I reck'ned untill morn, that as
a lion so will he
Break all my bones; from day to night
thou'lt make an end of me.

div.p: 5 Like a cran or a swallow, so did I chatter: I did mourn as a dove,

lg.l: Ev'n like a cran in my distresse,
or as a swallow sad
So did I chatter: as a dove
a heavy mourning had.

div.p: Mine eyes fail with looking upward: O Lord, I am oppressed, undertake for me.

lg.l: Mine eyes they long with looking up
now very failed be,
O Lord, I am oppressed sore,
do undertake for me.

div.p: 6 What shall I say? he hath both spoken unto me, and himself hath done it: I shall go softly all my years in the bitternesse of my soul.

lg.l: What shall I say? He spoken hath,
and als hath done no lesse,
I shall go softly all my years
in my souls bitternesse.

div.p: 7 O Lord, by these things men live, and in all these things is the life of my spirit: so wilt thou recover me, and make me to live.

lg.l: Lord by those things men live, in them
my spirit life doth take,
And so thou wilt recover me,
and me to live wilt make.
O do behold, how for my peace
I had great bitternesse,
But thou in love hast sav'd my soul
from pit of rottennesse.

div.p:
For thou hast cast all my sins behinde thy
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰

9 For the grave cannot praise thee, death can not celebrate thee: they that go down into the
â€¢ it cannot hope for thy truth.
div.l: My sins thou cast behind thy back:

lg.l: For neither grave nor death
Can praise thee, they that go to pit
cannot hope for thy truth.

div.p:
10 The living, the living, he shall praise
â€¢ hee, as I do this day: the father to the children shall make known thy truth.

lg.l: The living, yea the living shall
thee praise, as I this day:
The father to the children shall
make known thy truth alway.

div.p: 11 The Lord was readie to save me: therefore we will sing my songs to the stringed instruments, all the dayes of our life, in the house of the LORD.

lg.l: The Lord was ready me to save,
wee'l while we live accord
My songs to stringed instruments
in the house of the Lord.

div.head: CHAPTER. 1.
div.p: HOw doth the city sit solitary, that was full of people? how is she become as a widow?

lg.l: HOw is it that the City doth
sit solitary still?
How is she as a Widow now,
that people much did fill?

div.p: She that was great among the nations, and princesse among the provinces, how is she become tributarie.

lg.l: She that among the Nations
was great, and Princesse made
Among Provinces, how is she
thus tributary treade?

div.p: 2 She weepeth sore in the night, and her tears are on her cheecks: among all her lovers she hath none to comfort her,

lg.l: She weepeth very sore by night,
and on her cheeks are tears;
Mong all her Lovers she hath none
for comfort in her fears.

div.p: All her friends have dealt treacherously with her, they are become her enemies.
3 Iudah is gone into captivity, because of affliction,

lg.l: Her friends all have dealt treacherously
with her, and turn'd her foes;
Judah's gone to captivity,
because of many woes;

div.p:
And because of great servitude: she dwel
â€¢ h among the heathen, she findeth no rest: all
â€¢ r persecutors overtook her between the straits.

lg.l: â€¢ nd for the servitude that's great:
'mong heathen she doth dwell,
â€¢ e findes no rest, her took in straits
her persecutors fell.

div.p: 4 The wayes of Zion do mourn, because none me to the solemne feasts: all her gates are solate:

lg.l: The wayes of Zion they do mourn,
because there is none that
â€¢ ome to the solemn feasts, yea all
her gates are desolate.

div.p:
Her priests sigh, her virgins are afflicted,
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ she is in bitternesse.

lg.l: â€¢ er Priests they in great trouble sigh,
her Virgins more and lesse
â€¢ re grievously afflicted all,
and she's in bitternes.

div.p:
5 Her adversaries are the chief, her enemies
â€¢ sper: for the Lord hath afflicted her.

lg.l: These that are her adversaries,
the chief above her be;
Her enemies prosper, for the Lord
afflicted her hath he.

div.p: For the multitude of her transgressions, her children are gone into captivity before the enemie.

lg.l: And also for the multitude
of her transgressions hye,
Her children before th' en'my are
gone in captivity.

div.p: 6 And from the daughter of Zion all her beauty is departed: her princes are become like harts that finde no pasture,

lg.l: From her that Zions daughter is,
the beauty all is gone,
Her Princes are become like Harts,
that pasture do finde none.

div.p: And they are gone without strength before the pursuer.
7 Ierusalem remembred in the dayes of her affliction.

lg.l: Before the fierce pursuer they
without all strength are gone.
Salem remembred in the dayes
of her affliction,

div.p: And of her miseries, all her pleasant things that she had in the dayes of old,

lg.l: And in time of her miseries
things pleasant to behold,
That she had in possession
ev'n in the dayes of old,

div.p: When her people fell into the hand of the enemie, and none did help her, the adversaries saw her, and did mock at her sabbaths.

lg.l: When fell in hands of enemies
the people of her stock,
And none her helpt, the foes it saw,
and did her Sabbaths mock.

div.p: 8 Ierusalem hath grievously sinned: therefore she is removed: all that honoured her, despise her,

lg.l: Jerusalem sinn'd greivously,
she is remov'd therfore:
They all together her despise,
that honour â€¢ d her before:

div.p: Because they have seen her nakednesse: yea, she sigheth and turneth backward.

lg.l: Because that they her nakednes
have seen while she did mourn,
Yea, she doth sigh most heavily,
and backward als doth turn:

div.p: 9 Her filthinesse is in her skirts, she remembreth not her last end, therefore she came downe wonderfully:

lg.l: Her filthines is in her skirts,
her last end she not on
At all remembreth, therefore she
came wonderfully down.

div.p: She had no comforter: O Lord, behold my affliction: for the enemie hath magnified himself.

lg.l: No comforter she had; O Lord,
see my affliction,
For that the enemy himself
hath magnifi'd alone.

div.p: 10 The adversary hath spread out his hand upon all her pleasant things: for she hath seen

lg.l: The adversary hath spread out
his hand on what had been
All her things pleasant on the earth,
for she hath clearly seen

div.p: That the heathen entred into her Sanctuary, whom thou didst command that they should not enter into thy congregation.

lg.l: That heathen men had thus into
her Sanctuary gone,
Whom thou wouldst not to enter in
thy Congregation.

div.p: 11 All her people sigh, they seek bread, they have given their pleasant things for meat to relieve the soul:

lg.l: Her people sigh, they all seek bread,
and also they did give
Their things that pleasant are for mear,
their soul for to relieve.

div.p:
See, O Lord, and consider, for I am become
â€¢ ile.
12 Is it nothing to you, all ye that passe by? behold and see,
div.l: See Lord: consider, for I'm vile,

lg.l: Is it nothing to you
All passers by? See and also
this well consider now,

div.p: If there be any sorrow like unto my sorrow, which is done unto me, wherewith the Lord hath afflicted me, in the day of his fierce anger.

lg.l: If any sorrow be like mine
done to me, ev'ry way
Wherewith the Lord afflicted me
in his fierce angers day.

div.p: 13 From above hath he sent fire into my bones, and it prevaileth against them:

lg.l: He from above into my bones
sent fire me to assail,
And it in a most fearfull way
against them doth prevail:

div.p:
He hath spread a net for my feet, he hath
â€¢ urned me back: he hath made me desolate, and faint all the day.

lg.l: He turnd me back, and for my feet
a net spread in the way;
He hath als made me desolate,
and faint ev'n all the day.

div.p: 14 The yoke of my transgressions is bound by his hand: they are wreathed, and come up upon my n â€¢ c â€¢ :

lg.l: The yoke of my transgressions is
bound by his hand alone,
They wreathed are, and also they
come up my neck upon:

div.p: He hath made my strength to fall, the Lord hath delivered me into their hands, from whom I am not able to rise up.

lg.l: He hath my strength made for to fall,
the Lord hath me likewise
Delivered into their hands
from whom I cannot rise.

div.p: 15 The Lord hath troden under foot all my mighty men in the midst of me: he hath called an assembly against me,

lg.l: God under foot in midst of me
hath trod my mighties all,
In midst of me; he against me
did an assemblie call

div.p:
To crush my young men: the Lord hath troden the virgin, the daughter of Iudah, as in â€¢
wine-presse.

lg.l: So for to crush my young men all;
the Lord hath with distresse
The virgin Judahs daughter trode,
ev'n as in a wine-presse.

div.p: 16 For these things I weep, mine eye, mine eye runneth down with water, because the comforter that should relieve my soul, is far from me:

lg.l: For this I weep, with water down
mine eye doth run, mine eye,
For the comforter that my soul
should save, is farre from me:

div.p: My children are desolate, because the enemy prevailed.
17 Zion spreadeth forth her hands, and there is none to comfort her:

lg.l: Because the enemy prevail'd
my sonnes are spoil'd eachone
Zion she spreadeth forth her hands,
to comfort her there's none,

div.p: The Lord hath commanded concerning Iacob, that his adversaries should be round about him: Ierusalem is as a menstruous woman among them.

lg.l: Concerning Jacob God ordaind
his foes about him round;
Among them is Jerus'lem as
a menstruous woman found.

div.p:
18 The Lord is righteous, for I have rebel
â€¢ ed against his commandment: hear I pray you,
â€¢ ll people, and behold my sorrow:

lg.l: The Lord is righteous, for I have
rebell'd against his will:
I pray you people all to hear.
and see my sorrow still:

div.p: My virgins and my young men are gone into captivity.
19 I called for my lovers but they deceived me;

lg.l: My Virgins and my young Men are
gone in captivitieâ–ª
I for my lovers then did call,
but they deceived me.

div.p: My priests and mine elders gave up the ghost in the city, while they sought their meat to relieve their souls.

lg.l: My Priests, yea and mine Elders als
then up the ghost did give,
While meat they in the city sought
their souls for to relieve.
See Lord, my bowels troubled are,
for in distresse am I:
Mine heart's turn'd in me, for I have
rebelled grievously,

div.p: Abroad the sword bereaveth, at home there is as death.
21 They have heard that I sigh, there is none to comfort me:

lg.l: Abroad the sword bereaves, at home
there is as death we see:
They have all heard that I do sigh
there's none to comfort me:

div.p: All mine enemies have heard of my trouble, they are glad that thou hast done itâ–ª thou wilt bring the day that thou hast called,

lg.l: Mine en'mies all my trouble heard,
that thou the same hast done
They are right glade; thou'lt bring they day
that thou hast cald anone,

div.p: And they shall be like unto me.
22 Let all their wickednesse come before thee, and do unto them,
div.l: And they shall be like unto me:

lg.l: Do thou now let therefore
Ev'n all their grievous wickednes
come clearly thee before.

div.p:
And do thou unto them as thou hast done unto me for all my transgressions, for my sigh â€¢
are many and my heart is faint.

lg.l: As thou to me for all my faults
hast done, do them unto,
For now my sighs they many are,
my heart is faint also.

div.head: CHAPTER II.
div.p: HOw hath the Lord covered the daughter of Zion with a cloud in his anger, and cast down from heaven unto the earth the beautie of Israel,

lg.l: HOw Zions daughter hath the Lord
cov'rd with a cloud in wrath?
And unto earth from heav'n cast down
Israels beauty hath?

div.p: And remembred not his footstool in the day of his anger?
2 The Lord swallowed up the habitations of Iacob:

lg.l: And in the day of's wrath did not
to minde his footstool call?
The Lord the habitations hath
of Jacob swallow'd all,

div.p: And hath not pitied: he hath thrown down in his wrath the strong holds of the daughter of Iudah:

lg.l: And he them hath not pitied:
he in his wrath so sad
Thrown down by force hath the strong holds
that Judahs daughter had:

div.p: He hath brought them down to the ground: he hath polluted the kingdome and the princes thereof.

lg.l: He by his might unto the ground
hath made them all to fall:
The kingdom he polluted hath,
and Princes there of all,

div.p: 3 He hath cut off in his fierce anger all the horn of Israel: he hath drawn back his right hand from before the enemie,

lg.l: Of Isra'l all the horn cut off
in his fierce wrath hath he,
He hath drawn back his right hand from
before the enemie:

div.p: And â€¢ e burned against Iacob like a flaming fire which devoureth round about.
4 He hath bent his bow like an enemie:

lg.l: 'Gainst Jacob he like flaming fire
did burn which wasts about:
He hath his bow bent, like unto
an enemy most stou â€¢ .

div.p:
He stood with his right hand as an adversaryâ–ª
â€¢ nd slew all that were pleasant to the eye, in the
â€¢ bernacle of the daughter of Zion:

lg.l: â€¢ s an adversarie he stood,
what pleasant was to th' eye
â€¢ ith his right hand within the tent
of Zion all slew he:

div.p: He poured out his furie like fire.

5 The Lord was as an enemie: he hath
swallowed up Israel, he hath swallowed up all her palaces:
div.l: His fury he powr'd out like fire,

lg.l: God was as enemy:
He swallow'd Isra'l, he devour'd
he palaces so hy:

div.p: He hath destroyed his strong holds, and hath increased in the daughter of Iudah mourning and lamentation.

lg.l: His strong holds he destroyed hath,
and hath increasde anone
In Judahs daughter mourning great,
and lamentation.

div.p: 6 And he hath violently taken away â€¢ his tabernacle, as if it were of a garden, he hath destroyed his places of the assembly:

lg.l: He violently remov'd his tent,
as't of a garden were,
He of th' assembly hath destroyd
the places that are there:

div.p:
The Lord hath caused the solemne feasts and
â€¢ abbaths to be forgotten in Zion, and hath despised in the indignation of his anger the king and the priest.

lg.l: God causd in Zion sol â€¢ mn feasts
and sabbaths be forgot,
In his wraths indignation he
King, Priest, regarded not.
The Lord his altar hath cast off,
and loth'd his Sanctuary:
Her palace wals he in the hand
gave of the enemy,

div.p: They have made a noise in the house of the Lord, as in the day of a solemn feast.

lg.l: Within the house that is the Lords
a noise als made have they,
As if it for a solemn feast
had been a joyfull day.

div.p: 8 The Lord hath purposed to destroy the wall of the daughter of Zion; he hath stretched out a line: he hath not withdrawn his hand from destroying:

lg.l: The Lord hath purpos'd to destroy
his Zions daughters wall
He stretch'd a line, he not withdrew
his hand from wasting all.

div.p: Therefore he made the rampart and the wall to lament, they languished together.

lg.l: Therefore he made the rampart so
and wall for to lament;
They languished together then;
Her gates to ground they went:
He hath destroyd, and broke her bars,
her King and Princes thus,
Among the Gentiles scattered are,
the law no more's for us.

div.p: Her prophets also finde no vision from the LORD.
10 The elders of the daughter of Zion sit upon the ground and keep silence:

lg.l: Her Prophets also from the Lord
at all no vision found,
Of Zions daughter th'elders als
sit silent on the ground;

div.p: They have cast up dust upon their heads; they have girded themselves with sackcloth;

lg.l: In this their grief they have cast up
the dust their heads upon,
And they themselves have also girt
with sackcloth evry one;

div.p: The virgins of Ierusalem hang down their heads to the ground.
11 Mine eyes do fail with tears; my bowels are troubled;

lg.l: And Salems virgins hang their heads
down to the ground right farre,

lg.head: â€¢ 1
lg.l: Mine eyes they now do fail with tears:
my bowels troubled are,

div.p:
My liver is poured upon the earth, for the de
â€¢â€¢ ruction of the daughter of my people, because
â€¢ e children and the sucklings swoon in the
â€¢ e â€¢ ts of the city.

lg.l: â€¢ y liver is powr'd on the earth
for the destruction
â€¢ f people mine, because in streets
young children sucklings swoon.

div.p:
12 They say to their mothers, Where is corn
â€¢ d wine? when they swooned as the wounded in
â€¢ e streets of the city,

lg.head: â€¢ 2
lg.l: They to their mothers said, Where is
corn, wine for to be found?
â€¢ hen as within the cities streets
as wounded men they swoon'd,

div.p:
When their soul was poured out into their
â€¢ thers bosome.

lg.l: â€¢ 'n at the same time when their soul
the city all throughout
to their mothers bosome was
with sorrow powred out.

div.p:
13 What thing shall I take to witnesse for
â€¢ e? what thing shall I liken to thee? O
â€¢â€¢ ghter of Ierusalem?

lg.l: What thing for thee to witnesse now
shall taken be by me?
O Salems daughter what shall I
now liken unto thee?

div.p:
What shall I equall to thee, that I may fort the â€¢ , O virgin daughter of Zion? fo â€¢
breach is great like the sea;

lg.l: O Virgin Zions daughter dear
that I may comfort thee,
What shall I equall thee unto?
thy breach great's like the sea.

div.p: Who can heal thee?

14 Thy prophets have seen vain and f â€¢
â€¢ hings for thee,
div.l: Who is he that well can thee heal?

lg.l: Thy prophets they have seen
Such things for thee as meerly vain
and foolish als have been,

div.p:
And they have not discovered thine iniq â€¢
â€¢ urn away thy captivity; but have seen fo â€¢
false burdens, and causes of banishment.

lg.l: Thy sin they not discovered,
thy thrall to turn away
But burdens false, of banishment
the causes seen have they.

div.p:
15 All that passe by, clap their ha â€¢
thee; they hisse and wag their head at the d â€¢â€¢ er of Ierusalem, saying, Is this the city,

lg.l: All that passe by clap hands at thee
they hisse and wag their head
At Salems daughter, saying thus,
is this the town indeed,

div.p:
That men call the perfection of beautie, the
â€¢ oy of the whole earth?

16 All thine enemies have opened their mouth against thee: they hisse and gnash
â€¢ he teeth:

lg.l: That men beauties perfection call
of the whole earth the joy,
'Gainst thee thy foes their mouth make wide,
hisse, gnash their teeth do they:

div.p: They say, We have swallowed her up: certainly this is the day that we looked for: we have found, we have seen it.

lg.l: They say we have her swallow'd up
this surely is the day
We looked for; we have it found,
we have it seen alway.

div.p: 17 The Lord hath done that which he had devised: he hath fulfilled his word that he had commanded in the dayes of old:

lg.l: The Lord hath done what he devisd,
fulfill'd he hath by sword,
That in the dayes that were of old
he did command by word.

div.p:
He hath thrown down, and hath not pitied and he hath caused thine enemies to rejoice o â€¢
thee, he hath set up the horn of thine adversari â€¢
â–ª

lg.l: He down did throw and piti'd not
he causd thine enemies
To joy ov'r thee, the horn he raisd
of thine adversaries.

div.p:
18 Their heart cried unto the Lord, O w â€¢
of the daughter of Zion, let tears run down li â€¢
a river day and night:

lg.l: Their heart did cry unto the Lord,
O Zions daughters wall,
Let tears down still both day and night
ev'n like a river fall.

div.p:
Give thy self no rest, let not the appl â€¢
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
thine eyes cease.
19 Arise, cry out in the night:

lg.l: Give to thy self no rest, let not
cease th' apple of thine eye
Do thou arise, and in the night
cease thou not out to cry:

div.p:
In the beginning of the watches powre ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
thine heart like water before the face of the Lor â€¢
â–ª

lg.l: See that in the beginning of
the watches thou powre out
Thine heart before the face of God,
like water round about.

div.p:
Lift up thy hands towards him, for the life of
â€¢ y young children, that faint for hunger in the
â€¢ p of every street.

lg.l: â€¢ hy hand to him lift for the life
of thy young children all:
â€¢ hat in the top of every street
for hunger fainting fall.

div.p:
20 Behold, O Lord, and consider to whom
â€¢ ou hast done this: shall the women eat their
â€¢ uit, and children of a span long?

lg.head: â€¢ 0
lg.l: Lo. Lord, consider to whom thou
hast done this us among:
â€¢ shall the women eat their fruit
and babes of a span long?

div.p:
Shall the Priest and the Prophet be slain in
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ sanctuary of the Lord.

21 The young and the old lie on the ground
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ the streets:

lg.l: â€¢ hall Priest and Prophet thus be slain
in Gods own Sanctuary?

lg.head: â€¢ 1
lg.l: The young and old both on the ground
within the streets do ly:

div.p:
My virgins and my young men are fallen by
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ sword: thou hast slain them in the day of
â€¢ y anger, thou hast killed and not pitied.

lg.l: â€¢ ly Virgins, young men fell by sword,
thou hast them slain at last,
â€¢ v'n in the day of thy fierce wrath
thou kill'd, not piti'd hast.

div.p: 22 Thou hast called as in a solemn day my terrours round about, so that in the day of the Lords anger none escaped

lg.l: Thou hast as in a solemn day
my terrours round about
Call'd so, that in Gods day of wrath
none hath escaped out,

div.p: Nor remained: those that I have swadled and brought up, hath mine enemy consumed.

lg.l: Nor yet remained hath alive.
those that I swadled have,
And als brought up, mine enemy
consum'd hath in the grave.

div.head: CHAPTER III.
div.p: I Am the man that hath seen affliction by the rod of his wrath.
2 He hath led me and brought me into darknesse, but not into light.

lg.l: I Am the man that greef hath seen
by rod of his own wrath.
Now into darknesse, not to light
me led, and brought he hath.

div.p: 3 Surely against me is he turned, he turneth his hand against me all the day.

lg.l: Surely against me ev'ry where
he turned is alway:
He in his wrath doth turn his hand
against me all the dayâ–ª

div.p:
4 My flesh and my skin hath he made old, he
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ broken my bones.

5 He hath builded against me, and compas
â€¢â€¢
me with gall and travell.

lg.l: My flesh and skin he hath made old,
and bones hath broken small:
He 'gainst me built, and compast me
with travel and with gall.

div.p:
6 He hath set me in dark places, as they
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ be dead of old.

7 He hath hedged me about, that I cannot
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ out: he hath made my chain heavie.

lg.l: He hath me in dark places set,
as who of old be dead:
He hedg'd me, out I can not get,
my chain he heavy made.

div.p:
8 Also when I cry and shout, he shutteth out
â€¢ y prayer.

9 He hath enclosed my wayes with hewe â€¢
one: he hath made my paths â€¢ ro â€¢ ked.

lg.l: When also I do cry and shout,
my prayer out shuts he:
He with hew'n stone my wayes enclosd,
my paths made crook'd to be.

div.p:
10 He was unto me as a bear lying in wait,
â€¢ nd as a lion in secret places.

lg.head: â€¢ 0
lg.l: He was unto me as a Bear,
that lying is in wait,
And as a lion that is in
the places most secret.

div.p: 11 He hath turned aside my wayes, and pu â€¢ led me in pieces: he hath made me desolate.

lg.l: He turned hath aside my wayes,
and also more then that
He hath me pull'd in pieces all,
he made me desolate.

div.p: 12 He hath bent his bow, and set me as a mark for the arrow.
13 He hath caused the arrows of his quiver to enter into my reins.

lg.l: He bent his bow, he as a mark
for th'arrow set me so.
He hath his quivers arrowes causd
to pierce my reins into.

div.p: 14 I was a derision to all my people, and their song all the day.
15 He hath filled me with bitternesse, he hath made me drunken with wormwood.

lg.l: I to my people scorn, and song
all day was made to be:
He hath me fil'd with bitternesse,
with wormwood drunk made he.

div.p: 16 He hath also broken my teeth with gravell stones, he hath covered me with ashes.

lg.l: He also broken hath my teeth
with gravell stones in wrath,
And likewise in his rage he me
with ashes cov'red hath.

div.p: 17 And thou hast removed my soul far off from peace: I forga â€¢ prosperitie.
18 And I said, My strength and my hope is perished from the Lord.

lg.l: I good forgat, my soul thou hast
from peace removed far:
I said that from the Lord my strength
and hope als perish'd are.

div.p: 19 Remembring mine affliction and my miserie, the wormwood and the gall.
20 My soul hath them still in remembrance, and is humbled in me.

lg.l: Remembring mine affliction,
gall, wormwood, miserie;
My soul doth still remember them,
and humbled is in me.

div.p: 21 This I recall to my minde, therefore have I hope.
22 It is of the Lords mercie that we are not consumed,

lg.l: This I do to my minde recall,
therefore I hope in thee,
It's of the mercies of the Lord
wee not consumed be,

div.p: Because his compassions fail not.

32 They are new every morning: great is th â€¢
faithfulnesse.

lg.l: Because that his compassions
fail not in any case:
They evry-morning still are new,
great is thy faithfulnesse.

div.p: 24 The Lord is my portion, saith my soul, therefore will I hope in him.
25 The Lord is good unto them that wait for him, to the soul that seeketh him.

lg.l: The Lord's my portion, saith my soul,
I'le hope in him therefore:
God's good to them that wait for him
to soules that him adore.

div.p: 26 It is good that a man should both hope and quietly wait for the salvation of the Lord.

lg.l: It's good that both a man should hope,
and also quietly
For the salvation of the Lord
wait on continually.

div.p: 27 It is good for a man that he bear the yoke in his youth.
28 He sitteth alone and keepeth silence, because he hath born it upon him.

lg.l: It's good in's youth man bear the yoke,
He sitteth so alone,
And silence keepes, because that he
hath born it him upon.

div.p:
29 He putteth his mouth in the dust: if so
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ there may be hope.

30 He giveth his cheek to him that smi â€¢ et â€¢
â€¢ im, he is filled full with reproach.

lg.head: â€¢ 9
lg.l: His mouth he putteth in the dust,
if so there hope may be:
He to the smiterâ–ª gives his cheek,
fill'd with reproach is he,

div.p: 31 For the Lord will not cast off for ever.

32 But though he cause grief, yet will he
â€¢ ave compassion according to the multitude of his
â€¢â€¢ ercies.

lg.l: For God for ay will not cast off:
Though greef he cause, yet good
He'le pitie have according to
his mercies multitude.

div.p: 33 For he doth not afflict willingly; nor grieve the children of men.
34 To crush under his feet all the prisoners of the earth,

lg.l: For willingly he not afflicts,
nor doth mens children grieve:
Under his feet all prisoners
to crush on earth that live.

div.p: 35 To turn aside the right of a man before the face of the most high.

36 To subvert a man in his cause, the Lord
â€¢ ppro â€¢ eth not.

lg.l: To turn aside mans right before
the face of the most Hye,
God to subvert man in his cause
approves not willingly.

div.p: 37 Who is he that saith, and it cometh to passe, when the Lord commandeth it not.

lg.l: Who is he that saith, and it then
to passe comes in the land,
When as the Lord in any way
did not the same command?

div.p: 38 Out of the mouth of the most high proceedeth not evil and good.
39 Wherefore doth a living man complain,

lg.l: Out of the most Highs mouth doth not
both good and ill proceed,
Wherefore thus doth a living man
complain in any need?

div.p: A man for the punishment of his sins?
40 Let us search and try our wayes, and turn again to the Lord.
div.l: A man for his sins punishment.

lg.l: Let us to search attain
And try our wayes, and to the Lord
let us now turn again.

div.p: 41 Let us lift our heart with our hands unto God in the heavens.
42 We have transgressed and have rebelled, thou hast not pardoned.

lg.l: Let us lift up our heart and hands
to God in heav'n at last:
We have transgressed and rebel'd
and thou not pardon'd hast.

div.p: 43 Thou hast covered with anger, and persecuted us: thou hast stain, thou hast not pitied.

lg.l: Thou persecuted hast, and us
with anger cov'rd at last,
Thou hast us by our enemies slain.
and thou not pitied hast.

div.p: 44 Thou hast covered thy self with a cloud that our prayer should not passe through.
45 Thou hast made us as the off-scouring and refuse in the midst of the people.

lg.l: Thou with a cloud thee cov'rd, that through
our suit passe should not thus.
Th' off-scouring and refuse thou madst
in midst of people us.

div.p: 46 All our enemies have opened their mouths against us.
47 Fear and a snare is come upon us, desolation and destruction.

lg.l: Against us opned have their mouths
our enemies eachone:
Destruction, desolation, fear,
and snares come us upon.

div.p:
48 Mine eye runneth down with rivers of
water, for the destruction of the daughter of my people.

lg.l: With rivers ev'n of water great
still runneth down mine eye,
Ev'n for destruction that doth on
my peoples daughter ly.

div.p: 49 Mine eye trickleth down and ceaseth not, without any intermission:
50 â€¢ ill the Lord look down, and behold from heaven.

lg.l: Mine eye down trickleth, without cease
or intermission:
Till that the Lord from Heav'n behold,
and us look down upon.

div.p: 51 Mine eye affecteth mine heart, because of all the daughters of my citie.
52 Mine enemies chased me sore like a bird, without cause.

lg.l: Mine eye affectsâ–ª my heart, ev'n for
my cities daughters all:
Me without cause sore chas'd my foes
like to a bird that's small.

div.p: 53 They have cut of my life in the dungeon, and cast a stone upon me.
54 Waters flowed over mine head, then I said, I am cut off.

lg.l: In dungeon they cut off my life,
and cast on me a stone;
The waters ov'r my head did flow,
I said, cut off I'm gone.

div.p:
55 I called upon thy name, O Lord, out of
â€¢ he low dungeon.
56 Thou hast heard my voice, hide not thine ear at my breathing, at my cry.

lg.l: Out of the dungeon low, O Lord,
on thy Name called I,
Thou heardst my voice, hide not thine ear
while I do breath and cry.

div.p: 57 Thou drewest near in the day that I called upon thee: thou saidst, Fear not.
58 O Lord, thou hast plead â€¢ d the causes of my soul, thou hast redeemed my life.

lg.l: Thou near drewst when I call'd on thee,
thou saidst, Let fear be past,
Thou pleadst the causes of my soul,
my life redeem'd thou hast.

div.p: 59 O Lord, thou hast seen my wrong, judge thou my cause.
60 Thou hast seen all their vengeance, and all their imaginations against me.

lg.l: O Lord, do thou now judge my cause
my wrong all seene thou hast,
Thou their imaginations sawst
and vengeance 'gainst me hast.

div.p: 61 Thou hast heard their reproach, O Lord, and all their imaginations against me.

lg.l: Thou hast most clearly heard, O Lord,
how their reproach did fall,
And their imaginations
that were against me all.

div.p: 62 The lips of those that rose up against me and their device against me all the day.

lg.l: The lips of those that up did rise
against me evry way,
And their device mischievous all
against me all the day.

div.p: 63 Behold their sitting down and their rising up, I am their musick.

lg.l: Behold their sitting down, and als
their rising up for ill:
I in this case most surely am
become their musick still.

div.p: 64 Render unto them a recompense, O Lord, according to the work of their hands.

lg.l: Unto them in thy sury great
O thou, the mighty Lord,
According to their handy work
a recompence afford,

div.p: 65 Give them sorrow of heart, thy curse unto them.
66 Persecute and destroy them in anger, from under the heavens of the Lord.

lg.l: Unto them sorrow give of heart,
thy curse unto them render,
From under the Lords heav'ns destroy,
them persecute in anger.

div.head: CHAPTER IV.
div.p: HOw is the gold become dim! how is the most fine gold changed! the stones of the sanctuary are poured out in the top of every street.

lg.l: HOw is the gold thus dim become?
how's fine gold changed f â€¢ rre?
The temples stones out in the top
of each street powred are.

div.p: 2 The precious sons of Zion, compareable to fine gold, how are they esteemed to earthen pi â€¢ ohers, the work of the hands of the potter!

lg.l: The precious sons of Sion like
to fine gold in the lands,
How are they as earths pitchers thought
the work of potters hands?

div.p:
3 Even the sea monsters draw out the breast,
â€¢ hey give suck to their young ones: the daughter
â€¢ f my people is become cruell, like the ostriches
â€¢ n the wildernesse.

lg.l: â€¢ Sea monsters ev'n draw out the breasts
their young ones suck to give,
My people's fierce like ostritches
in wildernesse that live.

div.p:
4 The tongue of the sucking childe cleaveth
â€¢ o the roof of his mouth for thirst: the young
children ask bread, and no man breaketh it unto them.

lg.l: The sucking childe his tongue for thirst
to his mouths roof cleaves so,
The children young ask bread, and none
it breaketh them unto.

div.p: 5 They that did feed delicately, are desolate in the streets: they that were brought up in scarlet, embrace dunghils.

lg.l: They that did delicatly feed
in streets are desolate?
They that in scarlet were brought up
dunghills embrace for that:

div.p: 6 For the punishment of the iniquity of the daughter of my people, is greater then the punishment of the sin of Sodom,

lg.l: Of sins my peoples daughter did
the punishment is more
Then of the sin of Sodome was
the punishment before.

div.p: That was overthrown as in a moment, and no hands stayed on her.
7 Her Nazarites were purer then snow, they were whiter then milk,

lg.l: That in a moment was ov'rthrown,
no hands did stay on her;
Her Nazarites more pure then snow,
then milk they whiter were.

div.p:
They were more rudy in body then rubies, their
â€¢ olishing was of saphire.
8 Their visage is blacker then a coal: they are not known in the streets:

lg.l: Then rubies they more rudy were,
as polish'd saphire drawn:
Their visage blacker's then a coal,
in streets they are not known,

div.p: Their skin cleaveth to their bones: it is withered, it is become like a stick.
9 They that be slain with the sword, are better then they that be slain with hunger:

lg.l: Their skin it cleaveth to their bones,
it like a stick doth wither:
The slain with sword are better then
they that be slain with hunger.

div.p: For these pine away, stricken through for want of the fruits of the field.

lg.l: For piece and piece those pine away,
before to death they yeeld,
They stricken through are for the want
of fruits that fill the field.

div.p: 10 The hands of the pitifull women have sodden their own children, they were their meat in the destruction of the daughter of my people.

lg.l: The hands of women pitifull
their children sodden have,
My folk in their destruction
for meat them did receive.

div.p: 11 The Lord hath accomplished his fury, he hath poured out his fierce anger, and hath kindled a fire in Zion, and it hath devoured the foundations thereof.

lg.l: His fury God accomplish'd hath,
his wrath he out did powre;
In Zion he put fire which there
its ground-works did devoure.

div.p: 12 The kings of the earth, and all the inhabitants of the world would not have beleeved, that the adversary and the enemie should have entred into the gates of Ierusalem.

lg.l: Kings of the earth and dwellers in
the world would not believe,
That th' en'mie into Salems gates
to enter should get leave.
For sins of all her prophets vile
and priests iniquities,
That of the just have shed the blood
in midst of her that lyes.

div.p: 14 They have wandred as blinde men in the streets, they have polluted th â€¢ mselves with bloud, so that men could not touch their garments.

lg.l: As blind they wandred in the streets,
themselves polluted much
They have with blood, ev'n so that men
could not their garments touch.

div.p: 15 They cryed unto them, Depart ye, it is unclean, depart, depart, touch not, when they fled away and wandred:

lg.l: They cried unto them, Depart,
unclean it is, we say,
Depart, depart, touch not, when thus
they wandring fled away:

div.p: They said among the heathen, they shall no more sojourn there.
16 The anger of the Lord hath divided them,

lg.l: They said among the heathen, there
no more sojourn they shall.
The anger of the mighty Lord
divided hath them all.

div.p: He will no more regard them: they respected not the persons of the priests, they favoured not the elders.

lg.l: Hee'l have no more regard to them:
of priests the persons they
Respected not, they favoured not
the elders any way.

div.p:
17 As for us, our eyes as yet failed for our
vain help: in our watching we have watched for a nation that could not save us.

lg.l: For us, our eyes for our vain help
as yet th â€¢ y f â€¢ iled have,
We in our watching watched for
a Nation could not save.

div.p:
18 They hunt our steps that we cannot go i â€¢
our streets: our end is near, our dayes are fulfilled, for our end is come.

lg.l: They hunt our steps, that we can not
go in our streets ov'rcome,
Our end is near, our dayes fulfill'd
are, for our end is come.

div.p: 19 Our persecutors are swifter then the eagles of the heaven they pursued us upon the mountains, they laid wait for us in the wildernes.

lg.l: Our persecutors swifter are
then heavens Eagles, thus
On hils they us pursu'd, and wait
in desert laid for us.

div.p:
20 The breath of our nostrils, the anointe â€¢
of the Lord was taken in their pits, of whom we said,

lg.l: Likewise of our nostrils the breath
th' Anointed of the Lord,
Was apprehended in their pits
of whom we said this word,

div.p: Vnder his shadow we shall live among the heathen.
21 Rejoice and be glad, O daughter of Edom, that dwellest in the land of Vz.

lg.l: Under his â€¢â€¢ addow we shall live
among the heathen thus,
Rejoice, O E â€¢ oms daughter that
dwell'st in the land of Uz.

div.p: The cup also shall passe through unto thee: thou shalt be drunken, and shalt make thy self naked.

lg.l: The cup also shall passe ev'n through
till it come unto thee:
Thou shalt thy self all naked make,
and thou shalt drunken be.

div.p: 22 The punishment of thine iniquitie is accomplished, O daughter of Zion, he will no more cary thee away into captivity.

lg.l: The punishment accomplish'd is
of thine iniquitie,
O Zions daughter he'le no more
as captive cary thee.

div.p: He will visit thine iniquitie, O daughter of Edom, he will discover thy sins.

lg.l: O thou that Edoms daughter art
he surely visit still
Wilt thine iniquity, and he
thy sins discover will.

div.head: CHAPTER V.
div.p: REmember, O Lord, what is come upon us: consider and behold our reproch.

lg.l: REmember now, O Lord our God,
what is come us upon,
Consider also our reproch,

div.p: 2 Our inheritance is turned to strangers, our houses to alients.

5 Our necks are under persecution: we labour and have no rest.

And to th' Assyrians, for to be

9 We gat our bread with the perill of our

15 The joy of our heart is ceased, our da â€¢â€¢

17 For this our heart is faint, for these thi â€¢

19 Thou, O Lord, remainest for ever: thy

Revive thy work, Lord make it known

2 God came from Teman, and the holy ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰

3 And his brightnes was as the light, he ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰

He horns had comming, and there was

div.p:
4 Before him went the pestilence, and burn
â€¢ ng coals went forth at his feet.
5 He stood and measured the earth:

lg.l: Before him went the pest, and coals

He stood and also measured

div.p:
He beheld and drove asunder the â€¢ ations, and
â€¢ he everlasting mountains were scattered, the per
â€¢â€¢ ctuall hills did bowe: his wayes are everlasting.

lg.l: He look'd and sunder nations drove,

The hills perpetuall did bowe,

div.p: 6 I saw the tents of Cushan in affliction: and the curtains of the land of Midian did tremble.

lg.l: The tents of Cushan I did see
under affliction;
The curtains of the Midian land
did tremble evry one.

div.p: 7 Was the Lord displeased against the rivers? was thine anger against the rivers?

lg.l: Was the displeasure of the Lord
made 'gainst the rivers fall?
Or was thine anger that is great
against the rivers all?

div.p:
Was thy wrath against the sea, that tho â€¢
didst ride upon thine horses, and thy chariots o â€¢
salvation?

lg.l: Or was thy wrath against the sea
that thou didst ride uponâ–ª
Thine horses and the chariots
of thy salvation?

div.p: 8 Thy bow was made quite naked, according to the oaths of the tribes, even thy word, Selah. Thou didst cleave the earth with rivers.

lg.l: Thy bow was made quite naked as
thou oaths to tribes didst give,
Ev'n thine own word; thou also didst
the earth with rivers cleave.

div.p:
9 The mountains saw thee, and they trembled; the overflowing of the water passed by â€¢
the deep uttered his voice, and lift up his hands on high.

lg.l: The hils thee saw, and trembled all,
great waters passed by,
The deep his voice did utter then,
and lift his hands on hy.

div.p: 10 The Sun and Moon stood still in their habitations: at the light of thine arrows they went, and at the shining of thy glittering spear,

lg.l: The Sun and Moon stood where they dwelt,
of those thine arrows clear,
They at the sight went, and the shine
of thy most glittring spear.

div.p: 11 Thou didst march through the land in indignation, thou didst thresh the heathen in anger.

lg.l: Thou in thine indignation
through all the land didst presse,
And als the heathen people thou
didst in thine anger thresh.

div.p: 12 Thou wentest forth for the salvation of thy people, even for salvation with thine anointed,

lg.l: Thou of thy people wentest forth
for the salvation:
Yea ev'n for the salvation great
with thine Anointed One,

div.p: Thou woundest the head out of the house of the wicked, by discovering the foundation unto the neck. Selah.

lg.l: Out of the house of wicked men
thou diddest wound the head,
Discov'ring the foundation
unto the neck with speed. Selah.

div.p: 13 Thou didst strike through with his staves the head of his villages: they came out as a whirlewinde to scatter me:

lg.l: Thou through his village heads didst strike
with staves of his that be,
They as a whirlewind did come out,
and that to scatter me:

div.p: Their rejoycing was as to devour the poor secretly.
14 Thou didst walk through the sea with thine horses through the heap of great waters.

lg.l: Their joy it was as to devore
the poor man secretlie:
Through heaps of water great thou walkst
with horses through the sea.

div.p: 15 When I heard, my belly trembled: my lips quivered at the voice: rottennes entred into my bones,

lg.l: My belly trembled when I heard.
and at the voice anone
My lips did quiver, rottenesse
did enter in my bone:

div.p: And I trembled in my self, that I might rest in the day of trouble: when he cometh up unto the people, he will invade them with his troups.

lg.l: I trembled in my self, that I
might rest in dayes most sad,
When he up to the people comes
with troups he'le them invade.

div.p:
16 Although the fig-tree shall not blosso â€¢â€¢
neither shall fruit be in the vines, the labou â€¢
of the olive shall fail,

lg.l: Though that the fig-tree blossome not
nor fruit in vines shall be,
The labour of the olive fa â€¢
shall fail as all shall see.

div.p: And the fields shall yeeld no meat, the flock shall be cut off from the fold, and there shall be no herd in the stalls:

lg.l: The fields shall not yeeld any meat,
the flock als from the fold
Shall be cut off, there shall no herd
in stals be young or old.

div.p: 17 Yet will I rejoice in the Lord, I will joy in the God of my salvation.

lg.l: Yet I in him will now rejoice
who is the Lord alone,
I also joy will in the God
of my salvation.

div.p: 18 The Lord God is my strength, and he will make my feet like hindes feet, and he will make me to walk upon mine high places.

lg.l: The Lord my God hs is my strength,
he'le make my feet to be
Like seet of Hindes, he'le make me walk
upon my places hie.

MY soul doth magnifie the Lord, 2 And my spirit hath rejoiced in Go â€¢

My sprit rejoiced hath in God

div.p:
3 For he hath regarded the low estate of h â€¢
handmaiden: for behold, from henceforth all g â€¢â€¢ nerations shall call me blessed.

lg.l: For of his handmaid he did so

For lo, all generations me

div.p:
4 For he that is mighty hath done to me grea â€¢
things, and holy is his name.
5 And his mercy is on them that fear him from generation to generation.

lg.l: He mighty did great things to me,
and holy is his Name:
They that him fear from race to race,
his mercie have on them.

div.p:
6 He hath shewed strength with his arm, h â€¢
hath scattered the proud, in the inmagination o â€¢
their hearts.

lg.l: He with his arme hath shewed strength,

In the imagination

div.p: 7 He hath put down the mighty from their seats, and exalted them of low degree.

lg.l: He hath put down ev'n from their seats
those that most mighty be,
And also he exalted hath
them of a low degree.

div.p: 8 He hath filled the hungry with good things, and the rich he hath sent empty away.

lg.l: Them that are hungry he hath fill'd
with good things evry way,
And those that rich are also he
hath empty sent away.

div.p: 9 He hath holpen his servant Israel, in remembrance of his mercy.
10 As he spake to our fathers, to Abraham, and to his seed for ever.

lg.l: He helpt his servant Israel,
he mercy did remember,
As he unto our fathers spake;
t'Abr'am and's seed for ever.

div.head: The Song of Zacharias after he had been nine moneths dumb for not believing the angel Gabriel. Luk. 1. vers. 68.
div.p: BLessed be the Lord God of Israel, for he hath visited and redeemed his people,

lg.l: THe Lord the God of Israel
for ever blessed be,
For that his people visited
and als redeem'd hath he.

div.p: 2 And hath raised up an horn of salvation for us, in the house of his servant David.

lg.l: And of salvation he for us
hath raised up on hy
A glorious horn in Davids house,
who serv'd him faithfully.

div.p: 3 As he spake by the mouth of his holy prophets, which have been since the world began.

lg.l: As by the mouth of those that were
his holy prophets than,
Which have among his people been
ev'n since the world began.

div.p: 4 That we should be saved from our enemies, and from the hand of all that hate us.

lg.l: That from those that our enemies are
we should be saved heer;
And likewise from the hand of all
that hatred to us bear.

div.p: 5 To perform the mercy promised to our fathers, and to remember his holy covenant.

lg.l: The mercies promisd to perform
unto our fathers ever,
And als his holy Covenant
made with them to remember.

div.p: 6 The oath which he sware to our father Abraham,
7 That he would grant unto us, that we being delivered out of the hands of our enemies,

lg.l: The oath which unto Abraham
our father then he sware:
That he would grant that we from those
sav'd that our enemies are,

div.p: Might serve him without fear.
8 In holinesse and righteousnesse before him, all the dayes of our life.
div.l: Without all fear so might him serve,

lg.l: In holinesse alwayes
And righteousnesse before him als
of our life all the dayes
And thou O child shalt called be
the Highests prophet rare.
For thou before the Lord shalt go,
his wayes for to prepare.

div.p:
10 To give knowledge of salvation unto ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
people, by the remission of their sins.

lg.l: That so he might the knowledge give
of his salvation
Unto his people, by their sins
most free remission.

div.p: 11 Through the tender mercie of our God whereby the day-spring from on high hath vi â€¢ sited us,

lg.l: Ev'n through the mercy of our God
that tender is, whereby
Us on the earth hath visited
the DAY-SPRING from on hy.

div.p:
12 To give light to them that sit in dark â€¢ nesse, and in the shadow of death, to guide ou â€¢
feet into the way of peace.

lg.l: To light them that in darknesse sit,
and in death shade abide,
Into the way of holy peace
our feet there for to guide.

div.head: The Song of SIMEON. Luke 2. vers. 29.
div.p:
LOrd now lettest thou thy servant depart
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ peace, according to thy word.

lg.l: NOw in thy mercy lettest thou
thine own servant O Lord
At last by death in peace depart,
according to thy word.

div.p: 2 For mine eyes have seen thy salvation:
3 Which thou hast prepared before the face of all people,

lg.l: For thy salvation mine eyes
have seen for great and small,
Which thou prepared hast before
the face of people all.

div.p: 4 A light to lighten the Gentiles, and the glory of thy people Israel.

lg.l: A precious light to lighten all
the Gentiles far and neer,
And als the glory of Isra'l
that is thy people dear.

div.head: Georgii Buchanani hymnus Matutinus ad Christum.

lg.l: O Day spring from on hy
Cause passe away our night,
Clear first our morning sky,
And after shine thou bright:
Of lights thou art the Light
Of righteousnesse the Sun,
Thy beams they are most bright,
Through all the world they run:
The day thou hast begun,
Thou wilt it clearer make,
Wee hope to see this Sun
High in our Zodiack.
And there he beames shall shake,
Of a most golden hew,
Which fading flowrs shall make
Their colours to renew.
O make thy morning dew
To fall without all cease,
Do thou such favour shew
As unto Gideons fleece.
O do thou never cease,
To make that dew to fall
The dew of grace and peace,
And joyes celestiall.
This morning we do call
Upon thy Name divine,
That thou among us all
Cause thine Aurora shine.
Let shadows all decline
And wholly passe away,
That light which is divine.
May bring to us our day.
A day to shine for ay,
A day that is most bright;
A day that never may
Be follow'd with a night.
O of all lights the light,
The light that is most true,
Now banish thou our night,
And still our light renew.
Thy face now to us shew,
O Son of God most dear,
O Morning Star most true
Make thou our darknesse clear.
Nothing at all is heer
That with thee can compare,
â€¢ unto us draw near,
And us thy children spare.
Thy mercies they are rare
â€¢ f they were understood,
â€¢ rath due to us thou bare
And for us shed thy blood.
Like beasts they are most rude,
Whom reason cannot move;
Who do not for thy good
Thee most entirely love.
Make us mind things above,
Ev'n things that most excell,
Of thine untainted love
Give us the sacred seal.
In mercy with us deale,
And all our sins remove,
Thy self to us reveale,
And this our song approve,
Us in thy mercy move
To walk still in thy way
First make us sick of love,
And then with flagons stay.
Let us not go astray
To wander far from thee,
Thou art the onely way
To joyes that lasting be,
O that we light could see.
That shineth in thy face,
So at the last should we
To glory go from grace;
Within thy sacred place,
Is only true content,
Where God's seen face to face
Above the firmament.
O that our hours were spent
Among the sons of men,
To praise th' Omnipotent!
Amen, yea, and Amen.
